episodes.title: What Fuels Extreme Progroup Behavior?: The Devoted Actor Model in Group Contexts
episodes.description:
ICSA 2025 Conference - Montreal, QC 
-
Omar Saldaña, Emma Antelo, Andrea Escudero, Álvaro Rodríguez-Carballeira
-
What Fuels Extreme Progroup Behavior? The Devoted Actor Model in Group Contexts
-
Abstract: From the field of psychology, various theoretical models have been proposed to explain why individuals may engage in extreme behaviors, such as self-sacrifice or violence. The Devoted Actor Model is a recent theoretical framework addressing this phenomenon, particularly in the context of violent radicalization. This model posits that individuals who uphold certain sacred values and experience identity fusion with a group that shares these values—feeling a profound sense of oneness with the group—are willing to make exceptionally costly and extreme sacrifices for their beliefs and/or their group. Building on this premise, the present study examines the perpetration of abusive behaviors toward other group members, a dynamic commonly observed in coercive cults, as another form of extreme behavior. Specifically, the study aims to assess the willingness of members from various types of groups to engage in such abusive behaviors. To this end, a questionnaire was administered to over 300 active members of different groups, including religious, political, cultural, and personal development organizations. We explore the values that give purpose to these groups, whether members consider these values to be sacred, and what actions they would be willing to take to defend them. Furthermore, we analyze individuals' relationships with their groups, focusing on whether they experience identity fusion and how this relates to their willingness to defend the group, even at the cost of extreme sacrifices. The results of this study contribute to a deeper understanding of the psychological mechanisms driving participation in potentially abusive group dynamics. 
These findings provide valuable insights into the experiences of individuals who become victims of groups that promote such behaviors, thereby fostering a greater comprehension of the risks associated with extreme pro-group behavior.

episodes.title: Groups Can Harm but Groups Can Also Heal
episodes.description:
ICSA 2025 Conference - Montral, QC
-
Claire Alison Hams, Zoe Lambert
-
Abstract: This co-presented video discussion by Claire Alison Hams (Post Cult Counsellor and PhD researcher, University of Chester) and Dr Zoe Lambert (Creative writing Lecturer, Lancaster University) explores their experiences of designing and running two pilot initiatives, hosted online in 2024 from the UK, to support recovery for ex-members of high control religions, groups and cults.

In September 2024, Claire designed and ran a 6-session online 'Recovery Group', via Humanists UK for 10 participants. Individual applicants were pre-met for 30 mins to discuss the group rationale and to have opportunity to ask questions. This was specifically described as 'not group therapy' but rather a series of specialist presentations by 5 ex-member therapists, on a range of topics relevant to recovery from high control. These covered the following topics: understanding the unique form of grief experienced by ex-members, the concept of doors to recovery, loss of community & isolation, understanding boundaries and having a voice, and sexuality and relationships. The aim was to create a closed-group, psychoeducational space held by therapists, which allowed for group connection and discussion. In November 2024 Zoe, supported by Claire, led a 'Writing for Wellbeing' 3 session course, via Lancaster University for 10 ex-members from worldwide. Zoe explored with participants the powerful medium of writing into emotion, with a focus on 'writing for process not product', via journaling, poetry and story telling. Participants met with Zoe and Claire for 30 mins online prior to the course starting to provide an opportunity for questions and for them to learn about the background of the ex-member, whilst checking on their support network and reminders about self-care throughout the process.

Zoe and Claire candidly discuss both challenges, fears, benefits and joys of running these new pilot support initiatives, whilst sharing some of the anonymised feedback received from participants of both groups.

episodes.title: An Autoethnography of Experiencing Art Therapy Born and Raised in a High Demand Religion
episodes.description:
ICSA 2025 International Conference - Montral, QC
-
Nicola Brophy
-
Abstract: This autoethnographic account examines the experience of engaging with art therapy as a second-generation adult who has left the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. The transition away from such faiths often involves significant struggles with trust, fear, somatic reactions, and existential distress, as identified in various fields of research including psychology, sociology, counseling, and cult studies. However, limited research exists on creative therapies within this context. To facilitate a deeper exploration of the experience, the researcher draws upon her own journey, which has been scaffolded by personal therapy, education, and a safe, supportive environment, ensuring that the research remains ethical.

Using autoethnography, this dissertation delves into the researcher’s engagement with art therapy over a span of 20 months. It incorporates journal entries and documentation of artistic processes in both group and individual settings, highlighting the barriers encountered in therapy and how these can be navigated through using art therapy as a modality. The findings reveal art therapy as a powerful tool for stabilization, emotional processing, and self-expression. Additionally, the research emphasizes the critical importance of the therapeutic environment and the therapist's understanding of high-demand religions and religious trauma, particularly in the early stages of therapy. The capacity of artmaking to quickly access emotions and memories underscores the necessity for practitioners to have qualifications in creative therapy, along with an awareness of the experiences of individuals who have left highdemand religions.
subjects: The Church Of Jesus Christ Of Latter-Day Saints

episodes.title: Influencers, Ideologies, and Isolation: The Digital Rise of Exploitative Wellness Movements
episodes.description:
ICSA 2025 International Conference -- Montral, QC 
-
Kim Peirano
-
Abstract: In the age of social media, wellness culture has become a powerful force, shaping how we view health, self-improvement, and community. Beneath its glossy exterior lies a darker, cult-like undercurrent that can lead to isolation, manipulation, and harm. This presentation explores how influencers, ideologies, and isolation converge to create a modern wellness phenomenon with cultic features fueled by digital platforms.

Social media has amplified wellness culture, transforming it into a digital ecosystem where charismatic influencers position themselves as gatekeepers to exclusive knowledge, offering followers a sense of belonging and selfempowerment—despite their lack of healthcare training, while promoting questionable health practices and products. We will also examine the origins of toxic individualism, tracing back to the Reagan era, where the promotion of personal responsibility and self-reliance was tied to purity and moral superiority. This narrative of "self-made" success laid the groundwork for wellness culture’s emphasis on personal responsibility for health, which often shifts blame onto individuals for their own struggles, particularly in areas like chronic illness, mental health, and body image. The connection between purity culture and wellness ideologies will be explored, showing how the pressure to "be perfect" and "fix yourself" continues to influence how we engage with wellness today.

By examining how social media algorithms reinforce echo chambers, this talk delves into how wellness communities isolate followers from diverse perspectives, deepening dependency on specific health ideologies and instilling fear of anything that strays from those ideologies. Drawing parallels to traditional cults, we will explore how wellness spaces use manipulation, emotional appeals, and coercive tactics to foster a sense of loyalty, making it difficult for followers to escape.

The session will conclude with a call for greater media literacy, encouraging individuals to critically assess wellness content online and recognize the potential harms of becoming entangled in digital wellness movements.

episodes.title: Oh my God, I've Been Kidnapped: A Deprogramming Perspective
episodes.description:
ICSA International Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC
-
Ginger Zyskowski 
-
Abstract: In the 1970’s, cults were becoming more prevalent across the country. Young people were being recruited for membership and families were desperate to understand the attraction that captivated their children. This desperation led to an action called ‘deprogramming’ – a grass roots effort that was unethical and illegal. It consisted of kidnapping the family member and subjecting the person to hours of intense interrogation while trying to explain that he/she was under the influence of mind control. Having been a victim of a Ted Patrick kidnapping and deprogramming, as well as the victim of having my three small children abducted and taken across the country, will allow me to share the difficulties I faced resulting from such an extreme trauma and the lace of resources available to help with cult recovery and gain a better understanding of the complexities that accompany an intervention.

My cult recovery used the ‘Humpty-Dumpty’ method as I tried to pick up the pieces of my broken self and put them back together without any instructions. A better understanding of this process would have been appreciated as opposed to having judgements and comparisons thrust upon me. Whether the person is a walk-away, a castaway, or is kidnapped for a deprogramming, more needs to be done to help. I will share my story and my newly released book, ‘Shattered – One Woman’s True Story of Trauma, Coercive Control and Survival.’ My recovery continues.

episodes.title: Listening to the Ignored: Mapping the Identity Construction of Ex-Members Using Cult Rhetoric
episodes.description:
ICSA International Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC
-
Aled Thomas, Edward Graham-Hyde
-
Abstract: The history of minority religions has been marked by (often hostile) interactions between minority religions and ‘anti-cult’ networks, usually consisting of former members of minority religions and/or concerned friends and relatives. Since the advent of online communication, hierarchical forms of anti-cult organisations (such as the Cult Awareness Network) have faded, giving way to more fluid networks of exmembers and ‘never-ins’ (anti-cult activists who were ‘never in’ the groups they are protesting). 
Ex-member narratives have often been neglected, or even ignored, within scholarship on minority religions (see Wilson 1990). This paper seeks to remedy this by exploring the emergent forms of anti-cult activism activated in online spaces. It will demonstrate how online anti-cult discourses allows ex-members to navigate their lives following departure from a minority religion, in addition to framing their former experiences. The use of social media and podcasting platforms has allowed ex-members to publicly voice opposition and level accusations against their former movements, whilst allowing them to build an audience of ‘followers’ to engage with their activism. The paper will also demonstrate how these activisms have often developed beyond digital spaces into in-person protests and campaigns.

episodes.title: Using Art to Build Self Connection
episodes.description:
ICSA International Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC
-
Natalee Bigger Stockdale
-
Abstract: Self-alienation can be a debilitating symptom that halts the chance of normal living for victims of coercive control. There is a developing body of knowledge regarding the best practices for therapy, but there is still a gap in research for how to aid survivors of coercive control with clinical Art Therapy. Using Art therapy is an ethical and skillful modality that may be a helpful tool to aid in building self-connection after a person survives a cult. In this session Natalee will explore a theoretical Art Therapy directive. The art directive includes a drawing and coloring method to visually capture a personal somatic experience. An optional written process will be offered to inventory the environmental stimulus and attach language to sensations that result from the environmental stimulus. Through this method of documentation of events and bodily experiences a survivor can potentially utilize art as a recovery tool, selfconnection, and a safety container. Using Art Therapy as a tool can be used to build somatic awareness through providing reflective distance and while introducing opportunities for play. Natalee Bigger Stockdale Building self-connection through creative expression can also be a solution focused goal in therapy. Through the ethical use of Art Therapy with licensed and trained provider, Art Therapists can utilize visualized somatic practices to help clients externalize submerged shame and process in a contained and safe enough way.

episodes.title: Purity Culture: Unraveling Its Influence on Identity and Relationships
episodes.description:
ICSA International Conference - Montreal, QC
-
Liz Sallows, Dresden Andrea, Magdalene Leon
-
Abstract: Purity culture, with its emphasis on sexual abstinence as a measure of moral worth, is a powerful framework that has deeply affected many individuals, particularly within religious, patriarchal, and social communities. Though originally intended to promote sexual restraint, the consequences of these teachings extend well beyond sexuality, shaping individuals’ understanding of their bodies, relationships, and personal autonomy. As Valenti (2009) notes, these messages continue to influence individuals long after leaving the environments where purity culture was central, affecting everything from personal identity to relationship dynamics and self-worth. Purity culture has deeply influenced individuals within many religious and social communities, shaping not only sexual ethics but also personal identity, relationship dynamics, and self-worth (Moslener, 2015). These teachings are woven into many people’s self-concept, creating beliefs and patterns that are hard to unlearn and that can persist into adult life. For many, the effects of purity culture can be seen in how they approach intimacy, set boundaries, and view their own value.
With attention to both lived experiences and academic insights, this interdisciplinary panel will bring together speakers who have been directly shaped by purity culture, sharing how it has affected their lives and offering perspectives for those seeking to understand and heal. By exploring these personal narratives alongside research, we aim to foster understanding, inspire reflection, and provide resources for those impacted by purity culture, whether directly or indirectly. Prior to coming to this panel, we invite you to reflect on what purity culture means to you.

episodes.title: How the Media Gets It Wrong: Human Trafficking and Cults
episodes.description:
ICSA International Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC
-
Robin Boyle-Laisure
-
Abstract: Human trafficking is a federal and international crime, occurring at alarming rates. In the United States, every 2.5 hours, a child is taken by human traffickers.
Worldwide, it is estimated that 27 million people are exploited for labor, services, and commercial sex. Also, at least 2,500,000 Americans have joined cultic groups during the past 30-40 years.
Human traffickers and cult leaders share similar modus operandi. Cults and traffickers strategically recruit, groom, and coerce their victims for profit. The media portrays human traffickers as strangers snatching children off of the street. While these incidents do occur, it is more common for the victim to know the trafficker. How this relationship develops is the central point of this talk. I will highlight a significant increase in the traffickers’ use of the Internet for the exploitation of children and teenagers. I will also point out the lack of publicity about cult recruitment on college campuses, and the need for colleges to advise their students to be wary of recruitment. In my talk at the ICSA conference in Barcelona last July, I addressed common characteristics between human trafficking and cults. The talk in Montreal will touch upon those similarities, but it will also draw from research for my forthcoming book: “Taken No More: Protecting Your Children Against Traffickers and Cults” (forthcoming Bloomsbury 2025).

episodes.title: Respectful Conversations in an Increasingly Polarized World
episodes.description:
Respectful Conversations in an Increasingly Polarized World: What Have We Learned From Working With Current and Former Members of Cults and Victims and Survivors of Domestic Abuse?
-
ICSA International Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC
-
Rod Dubrow-Marshall, Linda Dubrow-Marshall, Kate Amber, Jennifer French Tomasic
-
Abstract: In a time when there is increased political polarization and conflict, the tendency to see the ‘opposing side’ as the enemy is almost overwhelming. Yet in the work that is done to help people exit and recover from abusive groups and relationships there is a widely acknowledged need to understand the attraction and nature of the trauma bond between the abuser or cult leader and those who follow them.
This approach mirrors the philosophy of ICSA in supporting open dialogue between individuals and groups with different views in the belief that this can bring benefits to all parties. At its heart, exit work or counselling requires a respect to be shown towards the victim or survivor while not ceding ground to the aberrant or harmful beliefs or practices into which they were coerced and indoctrinated (Giambalvo, 2018). In this roundtable panel discussion, four experienced professionals and researchers in the fields of cultic studies and coercive control will share and discuss their work with those that are victims or survivors of cults and domestic abuse and will draw out important lessons for working to depolarize the political landscape. Lessons for how to actively listen and encourage respectful dialogue will be applied to the task of bridging the huge divides in society post the US election in 2024. The need for re-humanization and the fostering of common ground offers the prospect of positive pathways from radicalized movements (Horgan et al, 2017), building on understandings from decades of exit and rehabilitation work with victims and survivors of coercive control across multiple settings including cults and working with survivors on their divorce and custody cases.

episodes.title: Acclimating to Life on the “Outside”:Catharsis Through Our Individual Stories
episodes.description:
ICSA International Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC
-
Debby Schriver, Lorna Goldberg, Alexis Broderick, Shaina Broderick
-
Abstract: Where am I, and how did I get here? We have lived on the “outside” of Tony Alamo Christian Ministries for 17 years and still carry our past with us. Family members and friends still living in the group are connections we never really break. As we try to acclimate to society, the learning curve that each one of us experiences is more accurately described as a mountain climb, with jagged edges, intruding rocks, starts and stops, and movements forward, back, up and down. Even though we are similar in age and lived in the same cultic group, most of us are moving in very different directions as we grow older. 
We all, even siblings, cope differently with our personal battles, victories, fears, and losses. We are people with layers inside of us, and while our coping mechanisms vary, our individual issues and challenges correlate once we zoom out and view our group as a whole. Panelists will tell stories of their ventures outside the cult, revealing their own mechanisms to cope with emotional conflict, fear, loss, and the elements that have brought them to the stage today.

episodes.title: Mental Health Literacy: Helping Others and Ourselves
episodes.description:
ICSA International Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC 
-
Sunny Naughton
-
Abstract: This presentation explores the intersection of mental health literacy with the recognition of signs and symptoms associated with cult engagement. Cult involvement can profoundly impact a person’s mental health, sense of self, and well-being, often manifesting in subtle behavioral, cognitive, and emotional changes that may be difficult to discern. Understanding these indicators can empower friends, family members, and mental health professionals to approach suspected cult engagement with empathy, awareness, and effective strategies for intervention. 
The talk will begin by defining key elements of mental health literacy and cult engagement, drawing on recent research that identifies cognitive, social, and emotional patterns commonly seen in individuals who may be influenced by cult-like organizations. We will discuss changes in personality, loss of autonomy, isolation from previous social networks, heightened secrecy, and an increased dependency on the group or its leader. Attendees will learn how these signs intersect with broader mental health indicators, such as anxiety, depression, and identity confusion, which can emerge in cult-influenced individuals.
Equally important is the emphasis on self-care for those providing support. Helping someone entangled in cult dynamics can be emotionally taxing, as it often requires sustained patience, boundaries, and resilience against potential emotional manipulation. This presentation will outline self-care practices that protect the mental well-being of helpers, including setting limits, engaging in regular debriefs, building a support system, and maintaining personal emotional boundaries.
By fostering awareness and self-care, this talk aims to equip participants with the tools to navigate these complex situations effectively, helping individuals transition to a healthier, more autonomous life while safeguarding their own mental health in the process.

episodes.title: It’s Our Turn to Speak – How an Apostates’ Podcast Is Changing Lives – and the PBCC Are Listening
episodes.description:
ICSA International Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC 
-
Cheryl Bawtinheimer, Ben Woodbury, Richard Marsh
-
Abstract: 
Segment 1 
Who we are, what we do and why– the history of Get-a-Life - Presented by Cheryl Bawtinheimer The Get-a-Life Podcast, launched in October 2022, was created by four former members of the Plymouth Brethren Christian Church (PBCC) as a platform for ex-members to share their stories and experiences. The podcast emerged in the wake of the church's ongoing “propaganda war” with its critics, which has included legal action to shut down anti-PBCC websites and blogs. The rise of social media in the 2010s provided a safer space for PBCC critics, with platforms like Facebook offering greater legal protection. Inspired by the success of media coverage, such as the Klondike Papers scandal, the podcast allows former members to speak out publicly. The podcast is recorded on Zoom, edited in Canada, and published on YouTube, Spotify, and Apple Podcasts, with episodes ranging from interviews with former PBCC members to discussions with cult experts. The format is informal, often emotional, and incorporates humor and satire. The podcast has grown beyond personal testimonies, now covering documentary-style episodes about specific issues, and has become a vital resource for those seeking to expose abuse and connect with others who have left high-demand groups like the PBCC.
Segment 2 
Opening doors and lighting up dark places – the surprising reach of Get-a-Life - Presented by Ben Woodbury The Get-a-Life Podcast has gone further than its founders anticipated, reaching three key audiences: 
1. Current Members: Despite strict monitoring of social media use within the PBCC, the podcast has found a way to reach current members, often through Dropbox links. These members access the content covertly, and some have cited the podcast as a catalyst for leaving the church. 
2. Former Members: The podcast is primarily aimed at former PBCC members, providing a platform for shared experiences. It has been especially supportive for LGBTQ+ former members excommunicated for their sexual orientation and survivors of sexual abuse within the church, helping them find validation and community. 
3. The Media: Public interest in the PBCC and other cultic groups has grown, leading journalists and documentary makers to approach the Get-a-Life team for insights and information. The podcast has become a valuable resource for media outlets covering the church and its controversial practices. Overall, the podcast has fostered connection, healing, and greater public awareness about the PBCC and its impact on individuals.

Segment 3 
Information, vindication, joy and pain, – the impact of Get-a-Life Podcast - Presented by Richard Marsh The Get-a-Life Podcast has had a profound impact on its audiences, far beyond mere education. For former members, it provides therapeutic value, helping them process trauma and challenge false narratives spread by the church. Many use it as a platform to counter the PBCC's smear campaigns, offering a form of self-vindication. The podcast also connects former members, fostering support groups for those with shared experiences, such as survivors of sexual abuse or LGBTQ+ ex-members facing rejection. For current PBCC members, the podcast challenges the church's controlling narrative by showcasing the successes and happiness of exmembers, undermining the church's claims that leaving leads to failure. Additionally, the podcast exposes the hypocrisy and scandals of the PBCC leadership, such as financial misconduct and abusive incidents, which are often hidden from current members. The podcast's impact extends to the PBCC itself, enforcing an unprecedented level of accountability. Journalists and documentary makers use the podcast as a critical source of information, helping to shed light on the church’s practices. By offering a platform for confidential whistleblowing, the podcast ensures that abuses are publicly exposed, making it a powerful tool for both healing and activism.

episodes.title: Research and Practice-Based Recommendations for Mental Health Interventions
episodes.description:
ICSA International Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC
-
Linda Dubrow-Marshall, Kate Amber, Jennifer French Tomasic, Ashley McLean
-
Abstract: It has often been challenging for mental health professionals to establish trust with former cult members who have experienced significant deception, manipulation, and betrayal. Dr. Linda Dubrow-Marshall will begin the discussion with suggestions for how mental health professionals can overcome these obstacles to provide a safe space for former members to examine their cultic experience and to begin a healing process that promotes posttraumatic growth and resiliency, as well as guiding family members to embark on a parallel journey that promotes healing for the individual and the family as a whole. Kate Amber will discuss the application of The Quicksand Model™, a comprehensive trauma-informed and survivor-centered framework that amalgamates decades of research on coercive control. The QSM™ combines images, alliterations and the metaphor of quicksand to quickly and effectively train professionals on coercive control from the perspective of the entrapped target. Jennifer French Tomasic will discuss her MSc dissertation research on how the Internal Family Systems model can usefully be applied to psychotherapy with survivors of coercive control. Dr. Erin Falconer will analyze the application of evidence-based and guidelines-based approaches to recovery from complex trauma and dissociation to cult recovery.
Ashley McLean will discuss challenges therapists will face in the recovery processes of working with multigenerational victims who have experienced coercion and how it is important for therapists to find a balance betweenfocusing on pre-abuse life events when in therapy and building identity during the therapeutic process. Ashley draws upon empirical insights from case studies. Dr. Linda Dubrow-Marshall will conclude the session with overarching principles of best practice for mental health interventions with former members and their families.

episodes.title: Addressing Spiritual Violence: A Transformative Change to Non-Violent Spirituality
episodes.description:
ICSA International Conference 2025
-
Aini Linjakumpu
-
Abstract: The presentation addresses spiritual violence, a form of physical or non-physical violence that a religious community exerts against its own members. It is justified by faith or membership in the religious community, and it violates a person's rights and reduces their possibility to define their own agency, spirituality, and future. The paper proposes a multilevel approach to tackling this issue: remediation, prevention, and direct intervention. Drawing on Susanne Moser’s theory of transformative change, the presentation advocates for gradual, deep change to address spiritual violence by engaging stakeholders and fostering collaboration. It analyzes policies, practices, resource flows, relationships and connections, as well as institutional mindsets and power dynamics. 
Based on the idea of transformative change, the presentation identifies five key methods for addressing spiritual violence. The first is “recognizing errors” by acknowledging past mistakes within religious communities, a process that helps shift from denial to responsibility. The second method, “supporting victims”, stresses the importance of providing non-coercive, compassionate environments for both current and former members, ensuring that victims of spiritual violence feel safe regardless of their relationship to the community. Third, “internal development” calls for the development of new social practices and theologies that promote non-violent spirituality. This involves revisiting religious doctrines to allow for flexibility and growth, fostering peaceful and supportive spiritual practices. The fourth method is “dialogue and connection” with society at large. Religious communities, such as churches and religious movements, should actively engage in societal conversations, collaborating with scholars, media, and other societal actors. The final method focuses on “structural responsibility”, urging the evaluation of laws and institutions to prevent spiritual abuse and support victims. This includes evaluating how societal structures can better prevent spiritual violence and support its victims.

episodes.title: Cultures of Control: A Qualitative Study on Coercion in Church Systems
episodes.description:
ICSA International Conference - Montreal, QC
-
Fabienne Harford, Rod Dubrow-Marshall
-
Abstract: This presentation will share findings about the ways in which coercive control may become embedded and reenacted through culture. Much of the literature on coercive control has focused on the intentions and influence of individual leaders. Within the area of Spiritual Abuse, existing research often focuses on an individual leader's personality or agenda. This research aimed to investigate to what degree cultural systems, structures, and language perpetuate coercive dynamics, perhaps unconsciously.
Directed Content Analysis was used to analyze published materials from two organizations across two phases.
First, 35 documents from a mega-church, referred to as “Church A,” were analyzed. Church A was a leading force in the 2000’s New Calvinist Movement and was closed in 2014 after its leader, referred to as Pastor A, stepped down following allegations of abuse of power. By exploring the culture of Church A outside the direct influence of Pastor A, this research sought to determine to what degree and in what ways coercive control was systematized.
The second phase of the research used DCA to explore materials from a related organization, referred to as “Church-Network.” ChurchNetwork, is a non-profit, originally formed by Pastor A, which aims to launch new like-minded churches and support existing churches through training and finances. While Church-Network separated itself from Church A in 2014, and denounced Pastor A, this study sought to determine if any coercive cultural practices from Church A had been unconsciously replicated through the Church- Network, potentially perpetuating abuse. This research provides insights that could help identify patterns of Spiritual Abuse and supports the potential that cultural elements could replicate and enact coercion without intentionality or awareness. These findings could demonstrate the usefulness of new preventive measures that address culture and have implications for broader understanding and protections around coercion

episodes.title: Mandated Shunning in Faith-Based Communities
episodes.description:
ICSA International Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC
-
Mandated Shunning in Faith-Based Communities: Building a MultiPerspective Framework for Understanding and Intervention
-
Windy Grendele, Savin Bapir-Tardy, Patrick Haeck
-
Abstract: For this theme, we propose presenting our initial findings from a global study on mandated shunning within faith-based communities. Mandated shunning is a structured and coercive practice, often enforced by high-control (cultic) religious authorities, that compels group members to ostracise those perceived as violating the community’s key tenets. This social exclusion results from formal or informal directives demanding cessation of all social and familial connections with the individual involved. The psychological, social, and economic impact on the shunned individual is often profound and enduring.

episodes.title: Maltraitance en contexte sectaire : le cas Guillot
episodes.description:
ICSA International Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC
-
Adriana Pacheco
-
Abstract: Dans cette communication, nos résumons un cas de maltraitance sévère envers des enfants au sein d’une congrégation protestante conservatrice, l’Église baptiste évangélique de Québec-Est, située dans la ville de Québec, Canada. Ces violences, effectuées par le pasteur de l’Église, Claude Guillot, incluaient la séquestration prolonguée de plusieurs enfants qui ont été soumis à diverses formes de maltraitance physique et mentale. Arrêté en 2014, Guillot a fait l’objet de 22 chefs d’accusation, entre autres séquestration, harassement, violence physique, violence physique accompagnée de lésions, et violence exercée avec des objets, et il a été condamné en décembre 2020 à 8 ans de prison. 
À travers ce cas, nous analysons différents éléments d’un contexte qui a favorisé la commission de ces violences extrêmes. Cette communication fait partie d’une recherche en cours sur la violence envers les enfants en contexte sectaire.

episodes.title: Cult Apologist, Anti-cultist or Social Scientist?
episodes.description:
ICSA International Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC
-
Eileen Barker
-
Abstract: Historically, those with a professional interest in the study of minority religions have been labelled as either a cult apologist or an anti-cultist. A few of us have had both labels thrust upon us. It is now over 30 years ago that I entitled my Presidential Address to the Society for the Scientific Study of Religion “The Scientific Study of Religion? You Must be Joking!” In it, I attempted to show that the social sciences cannot hope to emulate the natural sciences by providing invariable laws of human behaviour. However, by adopting the methodology of the sciences they can – and should – succeed in, at least, disproving some of the ignorance, misinformation and disinformation that surround the enormous variety of religions and spiritual movements to be found in contemporary society – and, perhaps, in providing a few insights that have eluded the conventional wisdom of the day. In this paper, I outline some of both the limitations and the potentials of a scientific approach. My conclusion remains that which it was all those years ago: “If the scientific study of religion is a joke, it is a very serious joke.”

episodes.title: Media That Sells or Media That Tells?: The Role That Media Can Play in DeCultifying Self-help
episodes.description:
ICSA International Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC
-
Jean Brown; Co-authors : Glenn Patrick Doyle, Deborah Goldstein
-
Abstract: In 2005, “The Secret” book and DVD blew up, touting the “Law of Attraction” to the multi-billion dollar/year self-help consumer market. James Ray became one of the franchise’s breakout stars, appearing multiple times on Oprah, as well as Larry King, The Today Show, and other mainstream media outlets. He was "the next Tony Robbins."
In October 2009, Ray’s success was halted abruptly when three people died at his Spiritual Warrior retreat in Sedona, Arizona. In the ensuing criminal trial, Ray was convicted of negligent homicide and served 20 months in prison. At that time, though the term “cult” was sometimes included in the conversation about this tragedy, the lack of understanding and lack of educated mainstream discourse about cultic phenomena was such that the term did not feel appropriate to what had happened. Yet James Ray’s use of cultlike tactics was clear.
This presentation will describe the role that the media played in enabling James Ray’s quick rise to self-help fame, and how the media was unable to adequately contextualize the tragedy of Spiritual Warrior. We will also discuss how media coverage of cultic phenomena in recent years has changed, thereby shifting the popular perception of cults and cultic phenomenon. The preponderance of storytelling through podcasts, docu-series, and memoirs has, to some extent, destigmatized the term “cult” while humanizing cult survivors. We will finally argue that the critical piece that media coverage must acknowledge is the link between the self-help industry and cults. Bridging these two ideas is necessary to protect consumers from abusive, cult-like leaders and groups.

episodes.title: How Do Survivors Move Forward? Exploring Coping Profiles After Leaving Abusive Groups
episodes.description:
ICSA 2025 Conference - Montreal, QC
-
Emma Antelo, Andrea Escudero
-
Abstract: Survivors of abusive and high-control groups face a unique and complex set of emotional, cognitive and social challenges as they work to rebuild their lives while healing from profound trauma. Coping refers to the ways individuals respond to stressful or traumatic events, as for example by seeking emotional support, planning, self-blaming, denying or avoiding certain feelings. Research shows that adaptative coping strategies can mitigate the adverse psychological effects of interpersonal violence. However, little is known about the specific coping style and strategies that former members of these groups use during their recovery after leaving the group. Thus, the objective is to identify profiles of coping styles in victims of abusive groups, and their relationship with the psychological abuse and psychosocial distress experienced. In this empirical study, more than 400 former members from different religious, pseudo-therapeutic, pyramidal, and other groups have shared their experiences. Through Latent Profile Analysis, we identified distinct coping profiles based on the 14 different coping strategies described in the literature. Are certain coping profiles more likely depending on factors such as gender, age joining the group, time since exit, or whether the person has received psychotherapeutic treatment? How has the abusive group experience shaped these coping responses? Are certain coping profiles linked to higher levels of psychological and social distress? By exploring these questions, our findings may help to understand the victimization and recovery experiences of survivors of abusive groups, highlighting the role of coping strategies in managing both trauma and dayto-day life. Furthermore, these insights may help to guide therapists and counselors in providing more tailored adjusted support for this population.

episodes.title: Measuring Spiritual Abuse in Demonic Deliverance
episodes.description:
ICSA 2025 Conference - Montreal, QC
-
Anna Kitko
-
Abstract: The phenomenon of the “deliverance” ministry, which encapsulates exorcism and demonic management, has increased significantly in the United States, Great Britain, and Canada as an alternative to therapeutic interventions for the treatment of regular mental health problems; the belief stemming from an underlying mistrust of clinical mental health interventions and of interest and support in movements focusing on spiritual afflictions. In many instances, clinical treatments for mental health conditions in and of themselves are considered in these movements as doorways or entrance and access points for demons to enter the mind and body of the individual seeking help. Consequentially, these deliverance sessions have come to be seen as a sacred alternative to modern medical or psychological interventions. The purpose of this talk will be to present the results of a recent exploratory study documenting empirically the level of abuse and psychological distress amongst survivors of deliverance ministries and to introduce a new psychometric designed to bridge the gap between the spiritual and psychophysiological realms, recently piloted successfully for the University of Salford, to measure said abuses, called the Deliverance Ministry Abuse Scale (DMAS).

episodes.title: Financial Trauma Impacts Survivors’ Futures
episodes.description:
ICSA 2025 Conference - Montreal, QC
-
Heidi Clemons
-
Abstract: Cult leavers and survivors often have a difficult time managing their personal financial responsibilities long after their coercive and controlling experiences have ended. The emotional and psychological distress caused by their experiences with money impairs their judgment and has significant influence in their money habits and behaviors, often leading to self-harmful money choices. A lack of adequate financial literacy continues to hinder trust and progress forward to develop adequate and healthy financial practices, made harder by the perception that personal finances are a socially taboo topic. Working closely with those who have experienced this level of financial abuse can change the trajectory of the survivor’s relationship with money and positively influence their future money decisions. Due to this financial trauma, it is necessary to provide a safe, non-judgmental, and empathetic environment for the survivor to explore their own money story, understand how it influences their financial decisions, and add the layers of financial literacy that have been missing. Through demystifying and normalizing the discussion of personal finances, and through sound financial therapy and literacy education, those working with cult leavers and survivors can facilitate and foster a new financial paradigm that will enable survivors to thrive.

episodes.title: Broadly Applicable: Cults and the Coercive Control Framework
episodes.description:
ICSA 2025 Conference - Montreal, QC
-
Sarah Feliciano; Co Authors: Chitra Raghavan
-
Abstract: The present study utilized the coercive control framework to systematically assess coercion in cults. Former cult members (N=121) from various groups (e.g., psychological & self-help related) were interviewed via telephone for 1.5 to 3 hours. The sample was diverse; 63.64% female, 77.69% Caucasian, and 71.07% American; age ranged from 18-68 years old. An existing codebook of coercive control tactics was used by multiple coders with high interrater reliability (93.18%). Coercive control tactics were present in all 121 narratives. Of the eight coercion tactics queried, manipulation, intimidation, and microregulation were most frequently reported. Sexual coercion/abuse, deprivation, and degradation were reported least. The primary coercer(s) identified varied considerably, as over half of participants reported the collective group as equally responsible in their abuse (56.20%) and a fraction of participants reported a pair or small team of individuals as equally abusive (10.74%). Data also provided coercive subtactics specific to cults but rarely noted in sex trafficking or intimate partner violence settings, allowing for a nuanced understanding of abuse. Overall, findings suggest the coercive control framework can be reliably used to assess how power imbalances are created and maintained in cults to entrap members. This is the first application of coercion control to cultic study of its kind, with strong implications for improved communication between cult researchers. Similarities and differences across interpersonal abuse contexts will be discussed.

episodes.title: A Psychiatrist’s Perspective of Cults
episodes.description:
ICSA 2025 Conference - Montreal, QC 
-
Cyrus Abbasian
-
A Psychiatrist’s Perspective of Cults - Extremist Violence & Vulnerability in Mental Health and Neurodiversity
-
Abstract: This presentation aims to examine the complex dynamics between violence, extremism, mental health, and neurodiversity, particularly in cultlike contexts. It explores how individuals with conditions such as ADHD and Autism, often coexisting with mental health issues, including substance misuse, may be at risk of cultassociated extremist involvement. Patients with anxiety, depression, and drug/alcohol misuse are more vulnerable to cult membership and exploitation, leading to extremism. Issues like reduced insight, lack of capacity, and safeguarding concerns will be discussed, with a focus on mental health factors that can leave vulnerable patients susceptible to manipulation and recruitment into extremist ideology. Drawing on clinical cases, I will illustrate how trauma and psychiatric diagnoses can predispose individuals to cult-linked extremist risks. Neurodiversity can make individuals more vulnerable to extremist influence. Special focus will be placed on the UK’s Mental Health Act and safeguarding principles. Additionally, I will explore overlaps with PTSD, addiction, suicidality, and dissociation. This presentation also aims to provide a psychiatric framework for understanding the risks faced by neurodiverse individuals in cult settings, and offer treatment strategies. I am not an expert in cults. However, I have 25 years of experience as a clinician working in the UK, and during this time, I have assessed and treated patients vulnerable to cult influence, some of whom have been convicted and imprisoned for related extremism. An important aspect of any mental health risk assessment should include vulnerability to cult exploitation, and current legislation does not sufficiently prevent this. Similarly, training for clinicians is lacking, as cult membership is often considered a personal choice. Given the associated harms, there is a need for more robust clinical interest and scrutiny of cult membership, especially among vulnerable psychiatric patients, with appropriate staff training, so this form of coercive control is taken more seriously.

episodes.title: Self-Care Practices as an Aspect of Religious Trauma Recovery
episodes.description:
ICSA 2025 Conference - Montreal, QC
-
Liz Sallows
-
Abstract: There are many aspects involved in recovery from cultic and religious abuse. Cultic abuse often carries with it the concept of putting one’s self or personhood aside for the betterment of the cultic organization. The teaching, both overt and covert, that one is less than worthwhile, damages the innate sense of who we are and who we can be. The reduction of self worth, shown by not caring for specific needs, not listening when someone speaks, not validating concerns and feelings, or being told the base nature is wrong, suspect or even evil, can develop an inner struggle of acceptance that one has value after all. A significant area of recovery from this abuse is the development of a healthy sense of self, along with a firm sense of personal self-worth. While this recovery can take time, the development of an understanding of the advantages of a self-care practice as a tool to enable recovery has been seen to be significantly helpful. This understanding is helpful for those who are first generation survivors, and those who have left as further generations. This will be a presentation of what self-care truly is and how self-care can be so beneficial to those who have experienced cultic and religious abuse. The presentation will share how self-care can be presented and implemented, for professionals in the field of trauma recovery, as well as those who are assisting friends and family members who are in the process of reclaiming themselves.

episodes.title: A Joint Healing Journey - Peer Based Recovery Models
episodes.description:
ICSA 2025 Conference - Montreal, QC
-
Andrea Silverstone
-
Abstract: This session presents findings from a PhD research study examining peer-based interventions for survivors of coercive control in contexts such as cults, intimate partner violence (IPV), and sexual exploitation. Practitioners from diverse fields—therapists, social workers, advocates, faith leaders, and lawyers—will gain insights into the various types of peer-based interventions, their strengths and challenges, and evidence-based recommendations for effective practice. Peer-based treatment models have proven effective in empowering individuals through recovery narratives, fostering selfefficacy, and promoting connection. Research highlights their value for individuals recovering from coercive control, as such groups provide opportunities to relate to peers with shared experiences, aiding in the reconstruction of personal identity separate from the perpetrator's influence. This session explores various peer support approaches, including secular, faithbased, and trauma-informed models, supported by research from Alberta et al. (2015), Buckle et al. (2014), and Goldberg (2017). Evidence suggests that psycho-educational recovery methods, when integrated with flexible methodologies such as Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) and Transtheoretical Models (TTM), are highly effective. Structured, intensive interventions, such as 16-week programs, yield significant improvements in reducing depression and increasing social support. The findings emphasize that peer-based support can be applied effectively in both individual and group settings, tailoring interventions to the unique needs of survivors. This session will synthesize research and practical insights from practitioners, fostering a deeper understanding of how peer-based interventions can empower survivors to rebuild their lives. Recommendations will address strategies for implementation, highlighting adaptability and the importance of shared lived experiences in facilitating recovery.

episodes.title: Collective Narcissism – A Lens for the Analysis of Cultic Groups
episodes.description:
ICSA 2025 Conference - Montreal, QC
-
Andre Jackson
-
Abstract: Collective Narcissism is the belief that one’s group is exceptional but not sufficiently recognized by others. It is a form of in-group love that is focused on an idealized self-image and feels threatened by a hated out-group. It can be assessed through four factors: Arrogance, admiration, entitlement and exploitation, and apathy towards others. This presentation will provide an overview of Collective Narcissism and its components. It will show examples of how Collective Narcissism manifests among Jehovah’s Witnesses, and invite the audience to discuss manifestations of Collective Narcissism in cultic groups and its usefulness in analyzing and describing them.

episodes.title: Her Voice When She Loves Me (or A Maternal Exorcism): A Solo Show
episodes.description:
ICSA 2025 Conference - Montreal, QC 
-
Zoe Lambert
-
Abstract: A script-in-hand performance of a solo show exploring cult recovery and messy grief. Adapted from Zoe Lambert's in progress memoir exploring her relationship with her devout JW mother and the traumatic impact of leaving the Jehovah's Witnesses, this show asks how do you forgive those who harmed you and how do you forgive yourself? The show is being developed with The West End Players in Morecambe, UK, and has directorial support from Ken Bernstein.

episodes.title: Les dérives sectaires dans les mouvements catholiques: l’exemple des Hérauts de l’Évangile
episodes.description:
ICSA 2025 Conference - Montreal, QC 
-
Christian Petitclerc
-
Abstract: Les Hérauts de l'Évangile (HE) sont une association internationale de fidèles de droit pontifical. Elle puise ses origines dans un mouvement brésilien d’extrême-droite : Tradition, Famille et Propriété (TFP) et de son fondateur, Plinio Corrêa de Oliveira (1908-1995). Derrière un combat idéologique se cachait cependant une vocation mystique : la croyance dans une apocalypse imminente, nommée à l'interne par le mot français "Bagarre", en vue d'instaurer sur terre un Règne marial au moyen d’un ordre de chevalerie. Après 1995, João Clá Dias (1939-2024) recentrera le mouvement, abandonnera tout aspect polémique pour se focaliser sur l’évangélisation et sera approuvé par le Vatican en 2001, mais à l’interne il y aura une radicalisation. Dans la vingtaine de pays où les HE sont établis, des activités sont organisées dans le but de recruter des adolescents pour qu'ils deviennent moines, esclaves et guerriers. À la suite de plaintes, le Vatican a nommé en 2019 un commissaire pontifical, un processus opaque qui ne semble pas avoir donné de résultats concrets. Un procès a aussi été initié à São Paulo pour aliénation parentale, torture, humiliations, abus physiques, psychologiques et sexuels. Les congrégations religieuses catholiques récentes ont très souvent les mêmes problèmes : emprise, système pyramidal, culte de la personnalité et obéissance aveugle. La majorité ont été réformée ou dissoute. Malgré un code de droit canonique qui ne prends pas en considération les abus psychologiques et spirituels, le Pape François a pris publiquement la parole, posé des gestes et enclenché certaines réformes en faveur des victimes. La Conférence des Évêques de France peut être vue comme avant-gardiste en la matière : elle a créé un bureau des dérives sectaires et établie une liste des dérives et des dysfonctionnements pour les nouveaux mouvements. Est-ce que cet exemple sera suivi en Amérique latine?

episodes.title: Silent No More: Defamation Risks to Survivors and Their Supporters
episodes.description:
ICSA 2025 Conference - Montreal, QC
-
Carol Merchasin, Pamela Takefman
-
Abstract: One of the goals of survivors and their supporters is to hold cults accountable and ensure that others do not suffer abuse. But speaking out often comes with risks -- being ostracized, potential threats to physical safety, and, in today’s legal climate, the risk of lawsuits. Cults often use defamation lawsuits to silence critics and survivors. This presentation will explore the essential elements of defamation, providing clear guidelines on holding cults accountable while avoiding legal pitfalls. We’ll begin by examining what constitutes defamation —specifically the false statement of fact that damages reputation, made with malice or negligence. Understanding these elements is crucial for those speaking out to ensure their words don’t become the target of legal action. Next, we will discuss practical strategies to avoid defamation in spoken and written communications. This includes using verifiable facts, avoiding inflammatory language, and framing opinions clearly as opinions. Transparency and fact-checking are key to making strong statements without crossing legal lines. We’ll also cover the status of AntiSLAPP (Strategic Lawsuits Against Public Participation) laws, which are designed to protect individuals speaking out on matters of public concern from retaliatory lawsuits. While these laws vary by jurisdiction, understanding how they can offer protection is vital for those challenging powerful groups like cults. Finally, we will outline what steps survivors can take if they are sued, including the importance of retaining legal counsel, dealing with frivolous claims, building a robust defense, and possibly countersuing for damages under Anti-SLAPP statutes. By the end of this session, attendees will have the tools to speak out against cult abuse while minimizing the risk of defamation claims

episodes.title: Mind Control and Intervention: From Cognitive Dissonance to Cognitive Balance
episodes.description:
ICSA 2025 Conference - Montreal, QC
-
Ingo Michehl
-
Abstract: As a former cult member (Moonies, 86 - 93), who completed his masters degree in counselling psychology with a thesis on Cult Trauma and Recovery, Ingo Michél explains mind control and possible interventions with American psychologist Leon Festinger’s Cognitive Dissonance paradigm and Robert J Lifton’s 8 criteria from the author’s book “Totalitarianism and the psychology of mind control”. Having experienced the subtle and subversive mind control techniques of the “Moonies” himself, and being converted from a liberal agnostic with a Christian background to a extreme right-wing religious fanatic within a matter of two weeks, working for free and being mentally, emotionally, and physically abused for 6 1/2 years, Mr. Michél explains how this transformation was possible, why a planned intervention by his parents failed, and how he was finally able to escape.

episodes.title: Child Sexual Abuse in Closed Religious Communities: Findings From a Large-Scale Quantitative Study
episodes.description:
ICSA 2025 Conference - Montreal, QC
-
Jill Aebi-Mytton, Cheryl Hope; Co-authors : Rod Dubrow-Marshall, Linda Dubrow-Marshall
-
Abstract: This presentation will address child sexual abuse (CSA) within closed religious communities. Situating CSA in a broader context, it will reference recent events underscoring the crisis of abuse in faith settings, such as the United Kingdom Independent Inquiry into Child Sexual Abuse (IICSA), the findings of the New Zealand Royal Commission of Inquiry on Abuse in Care and the Australian Royal Commission into Institutional Responses to child sexual abuse (2017) and more recently Justin Welby’s resignation as Archbishop of Canterbury. The core of the paper will highlight the findings from a large-scale survey run by the University of Salford, designed to explore the psychological well-being of former members of cultic group. It will focus on CSA within high-demand religious groups, gathering insights from over 600 respondents of the total sample of over 1100. This data, which reveals patterns of abuse prevalence, institutional responses, and the long-term impacts on survivors contributes new understanding to the complex dynamics within closed communities that may enable abuse, underscoring the need for targeted policies to improve transparency, accountability, and support for survivors in cultic group based contexts.

episodes.title: Bringing Democracy to the Troubled Teen Industry
episodes.description:
ICSA 2025 Conference - Montreal, QC
-
Adam Arnold 
-
Abstract: Horrific accounts from the "troubled teen industry" have been well-documented in documentaries, books, and on podcasts. Some call for these types of adolescent residential programs to be abolished, noting their implicit coercion and historic abuses. Others believe these programs are meeting a dire need in communities and that they must remain, with the onus on state governments to apply stringent regulation. The Democratic Youth Engagement (DYE) Model provides a traumainformed path toward reforming adolescent residential programs. This workshop will make known the historical concerns within the troubled teen industry, and provide new ideas for how adolescent residential programs can become empowering, healing spaces for the youth and families receiving their services.

episodes.title: Somatic Psychotherapy for Cult Recovery: for Therapists and Survivors
episodes.description:
ICSA Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC
-
Somatic Psychotherapy for Cult Recovery: for Therapists and Survivors
-
Nicola Ranson
-
Abstract: This presentation addresses how to safely access the wisdom of the body using somatic interventions. Topics include: Why resistance should be revered, how connecting to the environment through the senses can reduce hyper-vigilance, how the experience of pleasure can be a radical act, and how cultivating a feltsense of safety can be an antidote for a nervous system habituated to danger. Somatic psychotherapy is based on the body’s innate capacity to return to a state of selfregulation. It can be inherently empowering (and healing) to experience the source of one’s personal wellbeing as firmly located within our own physiology — the opposite of cultic indoctrination which externalizes agency. Somatic approaches have found their way into mainstream psychotherapy as trauma survivors and providers realize that a top-down cognitive approach can’t always address symptoms that are experienced in the body. However, invoking physical sensations by using somatic approaches can be tricky. For a cult survivor who has been abused by someone in a position of power, a therapist’s somatic interventions can sometimes feel more intrusive than regular psychotherapy, and well-intended psychotherapists may end up re-traumatizing their clients. Through both lecture and experiential exercises, Ranson draws from over 25 years of clinical experience and demonstrates how somatic psychotherapy can make it easier for therapists to see the subtle dynamics of trauma reenactment and find safe and appropriate interventions.

episodes.title: Tokyo District Court Orders the Dissolution of the Unification Church
episodes.description:
ICSA Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC
-
Takashi Yamaguchi, Kyoko Nagano
-
Abstract: "A new legislation about questionable donations" The Act on Preventing Unjust Solicitation of Donations by a Corporations was legislated as a response to the public concern and criticism over the fundraising practices of the Unification Church. This law prohibits organizations from soliciting donations by stirring up anxiety or otherwise confusing prospective donors. The concept of this law has been adopted by the Supreme Court of Japan Judgment, setting a new standard about the legality of soliciting of donations, which we will also be addressing. 
"Recent court judgments concerning the Unification Church Church. " On July 11, 2024, the Supreme Cout of Japan nullified a waiver letter for rights to court proceedings with respect to donations provided to the Unification Church and remanded the case to the Tokyo High Court, and by doing so, setting a new criterion about the legality of soliciting of donations, about how such solicitations may constitute tort.
The Supreme Court found that the Unification Church side “took advantage of the woman’s condition that made it difficult for her to make rational decisions, and the waiver letter is not enforceable as it goes against public policy.” We will discuss about the impact of this case it has on the recovery of the damages. We may also discuss about the dissolution motion filed by the Japanese Government against the Unification Church, currently pending in Tokyo District Court.

episodes.title: The Medical Workforce - Can They Become Advocates and Allies for Cult Impacted People?
episodes.description:
ICSA Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC
-
Caroline Ansley
-
Abstract: The medical workforce represent an influential body who are often as ignorant about the needs of cult-impacted people as the general population. They often have access to those still inside a cult — who either directly ask for aid from a doctor outside the group when they are unwell or injured, or are forced to access medical care due to urgency. The person may or may not disclose to their doctor that they are in a cult, though there are often clues for the astute and educated professional. Front line medical staff in New Zealand generally lack both the basic knowledge about cult activity, the ability to recognise a person who is in such a group, and the skills to support their recovery in a non-judgmental and trustbuilding way. In 2023 and 2024 a guidance was developed in New Zealand for health-workers - primarily for doctors, nurses and nurse practitioners - to use when consulting with people who either self-disclose that they are cult-impacted, or who rouse suspicion of such in the clinician. This guidance was developed with input from approximately 30 frontline health workers, survivors, and researchers. It is hosted by an online password protected website, which is used at point-of-care by community-based clinicians all over New Zealand on a day-to-day basis in their medical consultations. The publication of this guidance to support cultinformed clinical consultations increases substantially the possibility that cult-impacted people will find allies in their doctors, that their doctors will gain the important skills needed to approach them and engage their trust, and that health delivery will be better targeted to the specific medical needs to those traumatised by cults. In this presentation the author will describe the process whereby the guidance was developed and the response to the roll-out of the guidance across New Zealand.

episodes.title: Male Victimisation in Coercively Controlling Cultic Environments, A Case Study
episodes.description:
ICSA Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC
Emily Lehsten 

- 
Abstract: The purpose of my talk is to disseminate the results of my dissertation, which I completed at the University of Salford in Manchester, UK, under the supervision of Linda Dubrow-Marshall. I performed a qualitative case study that examined the lived experiences of six male former cult members over 18 using semistructured interviews and a demographic questionnaire to answer the questions: what experiences did these men go through, and why do these experiences matter? My research indicated that the victimisation of men in coercively controlling cultic environments is both similar and different to the abuses that women suffer. As there is little research on the abuses that men suffer in these environments, I used a thematic analysis to determine the themes across male experiences. Four themes presented themselves: Language is Key. Totalitarian language is woven into the men’s stories and plays a crucial role in control. 2. The Many Faces of Abuse. Each of the men survived many types of abuse, including spiritual, psychological, and sexual. 3. Achievement As a Means of Coercion. Achievement is used as justification for punishment. 4. The Aftermath. This theme looks at the trauma suffered by these men as it impacts their post-cult lives. The experiences of these men are relevant as their plight has been overlooked in the wake of radical feminism, hegemonic masculinity, and harmful stereotypes. The problem arises when men are not taken seriously in their efforts to obtain help once they leave their cultic environment. This research aims to shed light on the victimisation of men in coercively controlling cultic environments to spur further research and policy practice to provide a serious yet compassionate response to abused men.

episodes.title: Escaping the Cult! A Thrilling Memoir of a Radical Identity Change and Survival
episodes.description:
ICSA Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC
-
Escaping the Cult! A Thrilling Memoir of a Radical Identity Change and Survival
-
Cathrine Moestue 
-
Abstract: "What happens when a life consumed by a cult becomes a powerful story of survival and resilience? Join me as I unveil the truth behind my memoir 'The Cult - They Called Me Roxy.'" 
Would you participate if you had a chance to join a movement that could end world hunger? This is what my teacher in moral philosophy offered me when I was a 19-year-old student at Stockholm University back in 1984, with the historical backdrop of the famine in Ethiopia and a world that came together in Aid for Africa. I said yes to him, not knowing that his program was a scam, not knowing he operated under a false identity, not knowing I would be trapped for seven years. I came to believe in a conspiracy theory that changed my worldview upside down. I adopted beliefs that isolated me from my family and my authentic self. I became «Roxy». Following the release of my book in September 2024, I have been invited to share my narrative across various media platforms, providing a unique opportunity to engage in a broader dialogue about cultic phenomena. In this presentation, I will not only show the audience the trajectory of the different stages of identity change that I went through from the 19-year-old «cheerful Cathrine» to becoming a stern «moralistic Roxy,» but also explore the shifting perception of cults in my country. I will share personal pictures and describe how moral philosophy was used as a tool for manipulation and share with you a unique and personal insight into the radicalisation process and its push and pull factors. Together, we will explore the transformative power of storytelling and media in reshaping societal views, ultimately advocating for a more informed and compassionate approach to understanding the complexities of cult involvement.

episodes.title: Catholic Leader/Guru Sex Offenders: Why Are They Detected So Late or Never?
episodes.description:
ICSA Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC
-
J. Paul Lennon
-
Abstract: Over the span of the past 15 years the Catholic Church has been hit with a spate of leader/gurus accused of sexual abuse who for the most part seems to get off scot-free. In this quantitative study the presenter will examine some salient cases in an effort to discover common causes, the perpetrators’ evasion tactics, possible flaws and negligence on the part of authorities, and concluding with suggestions to detect, monitor, treat and prevent such recurrences as much as possible, Recommendation may be useful to other institutions in the helping professions.

episodes.title: Humor, Awe and Recovery from Cults
episodes.description:
ICSA Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC
-
Yuval Laor
-
Abstract: This lecture will concern the relationship between awe and humor (not laughter), arguing that these are psychologically incompatible. I maintain that understanding this relationship can, in some cases, help people in their recovery from cultic abuse. There are three main theories of humor. First is humor as incongruity, where something is funny when it makes people realize that they were mistaken. Such humor is incompatible with awe because, unlike humor, awe makes people feel that something is “really real.” The next theory of humor connects it with playfulness, and being unserious. This conflicts with awe which makes people feel that something is serious and important. Finally, we have humor that makes people look down on something by laughing at it. This is incompatible with awe, which often makes people feel that they are in the presence of something greater than themselves. In my past lectures at ICSA conferences concerned the emotion of awe, and its central role in cultic recruitment and other cultic dynamics. As such, memories connected to one’s former cult are likely to be coupled with awe, an association that could hinder recovery. I argue that the awe coupled with memories of the cult can be expunged by laughing at cult’s leadership and at one’s experiences and behaviors in the cult (when it is possible). Removing the awe connected to people’s memories of their former cult, can help them integrate what happened to them with the rest of their memories, which is likely to accelerate recovery. This means that laughing at the cult’s leaders, practices and beliefs can be used to facilitate recovery. I suspect that particularly effective is meeting with other former members, where “inside jokes” can be used to laugh at a shared cultic past.

episodes.title: Intergenerational Transmission of Cult Trauma
episodes.description:
ICSA Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC
-
Intergenerational Transmission of Cult Trauma: The Impact of Cult-Created Dissociation and a Cult-Created Harsh Conscience on Child-Rearing
-
Lorna Goldberg, Doni Whitsett, William Goldberg; Co-authors : Dan Spence
-
Abstract: As a result of cult trauma and ongoing cult practices, typically, cult parents are living in a cult-induced dissociative state, which interferes with their ability to self-reflect and provide an empathic connection with their children. Instead, cult parents become malleable in following the self-serving demands of their leader rather than following their own inclinations. Typically, cult practices leave their children vulnerable to emotional and physical neglect and abuse. To illustrate this process, the speaker will describe a relationship between a second-generation mother and her third-generation son. This relationship will be presented as an example of intergenerational transmission of cult trauma. To clarify this process, the speaker will define “dissociation” and examine theories of early development, including how the mother-child early relationship impacts the brain and nervous system. This will provide insight into the thirdgeneration son’s early life experience and the consequences for adulthood. The speaker also will discuss the post-cult recovery process for a mother and her son, including the impact of collaborating on this paper. She will offer therapeutic recommendations for working with former cult members, highlighting the need to address transference and countertransference reactions, cult-induced dissociation and dysregulation, as well as the harsh conscience created by the cult.

episodes.title: Investigating the Psychological Health and Wellbeing of Former Members of Cultic Groups
episodes.description:
ICSA Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC
-
Jill Aebi-Mytton; Co-authors : Rod Dubrow-Marshall, Linda Dubrow-Marshall
-
Investigating the Psychological Health and Wellbeing of Former Members of Cultic Groups: are there differences between those born in and/or raised, and those who join?
-
Abstract: This presentation will address child sexual abuse (CSA) within closed religious communities. Situating CSA in a broader context, it will reference recent events underscoring the crisis of abuse in faith settings, such as the United Kingdom Independent Inquiry into Child Sexual Abuse (IICSA), the findings of the New Zealand Royal Commission of Inquiry on Abuse in Care and the Australian Royal Commission into Institutional Responses to child sexual abuse (2017) and more recently Justin Welby’s resignation as Archbishop of Canterbury.
The core of the paper will highlight the findings from a large-scale survey run by the University of Salford, designed to explore the psychological well-being of former members of cultic group. It will focus on CSA within high-demand religious groups, gathering insights from over 600 respondents of the total sample of over 1100. This data, which reveals patterns of abuse prevalence, institutional responses, and the long-term impacts on survivors contributes new understanding to the complex dynamics within closed communities that may enable abuse, underscoring the need for targeted policies to improve transparency, accountability, and support for survivors in cultic group based contexts.

episodes.title: Dissociation and Mindfulness: Mental Health Needs and Coping Strategies of Youth Raised in Cultic
episodes.description:
ICSA Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC
-
Dissociation and Mindfulness: Mental Health Needs and Coping Strategies of Youth Raised in Cultic and High-Control Groups
-
Luna Cappelletti; Co-authors : Andra Smith, Angela Katherine Boland, William Wright
-
Abstract: Young people experience many stressors and have found variable methods to deal with them. Some, but certainly not an exhaustive list, include mindfulness, drug and/or alcohol use, religiosity, and dissociation. Each one can involve an altered state of consciousness. Mindfulness is a mental state characterized by the ability to be attentive and accepting of the present moment, and has been highlighted in recent years as a valuable stress management technique. Conversely, dissociation is marked by a discontinuity between the self and physical experiences, resulting in detachment from the present moment. Although dissociation is generally seen as pathological, examples of both dissociation and mindfulness practices can be found in various religious practices, and little research has compared the two in the context of religion. This relationship may be further complicated for former members of cultic and high-control religious groups, where practices like meditation that are often associated with mindfulness are sometimes used to elicit a disconnect from the self and the environment in a problematic way. In this presentation, we examine recent data collected from a university student sample and two community samples and compare scores of religiosity, mindfulness, substance use, dissociation, and well-being between current and former members of major and cultic/high-control religious groups. We also contextualize past mindfulness and dissociation research to cultic studies and highlight the potential drawbacks and benefits of comparing former members of major versus cultic and highcontrol religious groups in a research context.

A Collaborative Approach to Addressing a Loved One's Cult-Related Involvement
