This talk will explore the vital elements of our collaborative approach (mental health professionals, former members, and exit counselors) using examples to illustrate these elements. A case presentation with a round table discussion from various perspectives, including interventionists, mental health professionals, research, and sociology.

episodes.title: Types of Trauma Therapy and How to Choose a Therapist
episodes.description:
ICSA Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC
-
Types of Trauma Therapy and How to Choose a Therapist
-
Abstract: Everyone recommends for Cult Survivors and their family members to go to therapy. It is typically easy to do a google search and find a therapist near you, but sometimes the hard part is knowing what trauma and Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) is, what options of therapy there are, and how to choose a therapist. This presentation will discuss types of trauma, the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorder, 5th Edition Text Revision (DSM-5-TR), and what trauma informed care is. We will explore different types of trauma therapy including Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR), Internal Family Systems (IFS), Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT), Trauma-Focused Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (TF-CBT), and others. We will discuss information about what to look for in a therapist including personality fit, licensing, certifications, and education. Along with things to consider such as payment options, cultural backgrounds, questions to ask yourself, positives in a therapist and negative in a therapist.

episodes.title: The Landmark Grenville Christian College Lawsuit: A tale of Two Plaintiffs
episodes.description:
ICSA Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC
-
 Beth Granger and Jacqueline Gagnon
-
The Landmark Grenville Christian College Lawsuit: A tale of Two Plaintiffs
-
Abstract: Beth Granger and Jacqueline Gagnon helped spearhead a lawsuit against their cult that would become the first historical abuse case to win at trial in Canada. In this session Beth and Jacqueline will discuss the complexities and challenges of pursuing legal action against their abusers, drawing from their deeply personal journeys. As former students of a cult masquerading as an elite Canadian boarding school, they will share their compelling narratives, and the lessons learned throughout a 16-year legal battle. Granger and Gagnon will start with an overview of their unique experiences—Jacqueline's early recognition of cult behavior and Beth's realization after escaping decades of indoctrination. This will set the stage for revealing what they learned about harnessing the justice system to hold their abusers accountable. They will share many lessons they learned along the way that would have helped them from the outset. Spoiler alert: Suing a cult, even one that went bankrupt, is not for the faint of heart. However, looking back, Beth and Jacqueline have no regrets. Despite the toll of litigation, they aim to illustrate how the journey led to healing and even societal change, setting legal precedents for future victims of systemic abuse.
Beth and Jacqueline are not legal experts and aren’t able to offer legal advice. They are, however, well acquainted with the challenges cult survivors might face when pursuing justice. This session will resonate with former cult members, mental health professionals, legal advocates, and anyone interested in the intersection of trauma, justice, and recovery. Their presentation will not only educate attendees about the legal landscape surrounding cults but also inspire them to reclaim their narratives. By sharing their experiences, they hope to foster a supportive dialogue that empowers survivors and advocates alike.

episodes.title: Navigating the Journey Out: Intervention Strategies for Supporting Current and Former JW
episodes.description:
ICSA Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC
-
Navigating the Journey Out: Intervention Strategies for Supporting Current and Former Jehovah’s Witnesses Members from the High-Control Religious Organization, The Watchtower Society
-
Michael Miller
-
Abstract: This study explores intervention strategies for supporting former members of high-control groups, specifically Jehovah’s Witnesses, during transition periods of autonomy, critical thinking, and personal growth. High-control groups often impose rigid, unorthodox belief systems and restrictive social practices, making disaffiliation, disassociation, disfellowshipping, and shunning a complex and emotional process.
The following five research questions guided this study: How do current and former JW members of high-control groups navigate their transition out of the group, particularly regarding emotional, social, and spiritual adjustments? What are the primary challenges that current and former JW members of high-control groups face when dealing with the effects of group affiliation or disaffiliation? What intervention strategies can support current and former JW members in rebuilding healthy relationships and reintegrating into society? How do current and former JW members of high-control groups reconcile their past belief systems with their current values and worldviews? and What role do professionals (counselors, therapists, religious leaders, and many other professionals) play in facilitating effective interventions for current and former JW members? This phenomenological study aims to understand the lived experiences of individuals leaving the high-control religious organization, The Watchtower Society (TWS), and their day-today challenges.

episodes.title: Integrative Therapeutic and Systemic Approaches to Cult Recovery Trauma Informed Healing and Family
episodes.description:
ICSA Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC
-
Integrative Therapeutic and Systemic Approaches to Cult Recovery: TraumaInformed Healing and Family/Community Support Models
-
Sharon Doni
-
Abstract: The Israeli Center for Cult Victims, the only organization of its kind in the country, has developed a multifaceted approach over the past decade to support individuals affected by cults and their families. In this lecture, I will outline some of the center's core tools and strategies, drawing on real-life case studies and examples to illustrate the challenges and solutions encountered in this critical work. Despite Israel's relatively small population of under 10 million, over 150 active cults have been documented. As the sole national resource dedicated to cult victims and their families, the Center has developed a holistic "360-degree" approach to address a wide range of needs, from mental health support and legal counsel to assistance navigating social benefits, guidance through judicial processes, and efforts to dismantle harmful cult structures. Throughout the presentation, I will share key real-world scenarios, including: How the Center approaches the initial interaction with cult victims, ensuring their immediate safety and emotional support. -A case in which a cult leader was discovered operating within a statesupervised shelter for at-risk youth, and the steps taken to address this serious issue; the protocols followed when criminal acts related to cults are reported, and the challenges of navigating the legal system in these cases; the various services that cult victims and their families require, and the importance of offering flexible, tailored support to meet their diverse needs; the Center’s response when Goel Ratzon, the leader of a notorious polygamous cult, was not convicted of enslavement despite widespread evidence of abuse. These examples will illustrate the complexities of working with cult victims, and highlight the Center’s best practices for providing comprehensive, compassionate, and effective support. I will also discuss how these strategies can be adapted in different cultural and legal contexts to maximize their impact.

episodes.title: The Perception of Sectarian Phenomena within the Society and the Role of the Media in France
episodes.description:
ICSA Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC

The Perception of Sectarian Phenomena within the Society and the Role of the Media in France: What Consequences in the Context of Legal Proceedings? 
-
Maleine Pictoin-Gueye, Ophélie Rodrigues
-
Abstract: The objective will be to examine all the consequences of the perception of sectarian phenomena in society as well as the role of the media in terms of legal proceedings in France. We'll be looking at both the role of traditional media and the not-inconsiderable role of new “media” such as social networks. We'll also deal with how lawyers can use the media in the interests of the proceedings, and play a preventive role regarding these issues.
The lawyer will need to use both the role of the traditional media and that of the new “media” in order to broaden the dissemination of information. The judicious use of the media can be highly beneficial in bringing a case to trial. But the lawyer will have to fight against society's perception about sectarian phenomenon which is sometimes wrong. The same perception of the sectarian phenomenon, is more often conveyed by the media. This misperception can even be disseminated in courts and tribunals, by also legal professionals. However, preventive information can be beneficial in combating a perception of the sectarian phenomenon which is not in line with reality. We will therefore begin by examining how lawyers can play a preventive role in combating misinformation about sectarian phenomena (I) and, secondly, how the lawyer must fight for a proper trial and a fair assessment of the sectarian phenomenon, despite the image conveyed within society and/or by the media (II).

episodes.title: Points tournants dans les trajectoires de vie
episodes.description:
ICSA International Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC
-
Points tournants dans les trajectoires de vie : comment les membres sortants de première et de multigénération construisent leur sortie et leur vie audelà des groupes à haute intensité d’engagement
-
Céleste Goguen
-
Abstract: This presentation will describe the role that the media played in enabling James Ray’s quick rise to self-help fame, and how the media was unable to adequately contextualize the tragedy of Spiritual Warrior. We will also discuss how media coverage of cultic phenomena in recent years has changed, thereby shifting the popular perception of cults and cultic phenomenon. The preponderance of storytelling through podcasts, docu-series, and memoirs has, to some extent, destigmatized the term “cult” while humanizing cult survivors. We will finally argue that the critical piece that media coverage must acknowledge is the link between the self-help industry and cults. Bridging these two ideas is necessary to protect consumers from abusive, cult-like leaders and groups.
Cette communication vise à identifier les « points tournants », c’est-à-dire les moments que les ex-membres de première génération et de multigénération reconnaissent comme déterminants dans leur décision de quitter le groupe. Ces points de bascule sont également importants pour leur capacité à s’adapter à la vie en dehors du groupe. Pour ce faire, nous analyserons les récits de 21 personnes qui ont vécu dans des groupes haute intensité d’engagement. En adoptant une approche narrative, il ne s’agira pas seulement de relater les événements individuels, mais de comprendre comment ces moments ont façonné et influencé leurs comportements après leur sortie. Comme le souligne Presser (2015), « les individus ont tendance à agir en cohérence avec les récits qu’ils construisent sur eux-mêmes » (p. 70).

episodes.title: Comprendre et traiter l'abus spirituel en psychothérapie
episodes.description:
ICSA International Conference 2025 - Montreal, QC
-

Abstract: Nous commencerons par définir ce qu'est l'abus spirituel, en mettant en lumière ses différentes formes, notamment l'exploitation émotionnelle, la manipulation mentale et les atteintes à l'intégrité spirituelle. Nous aborderons ensuite les principaux traits de l'emprise relationnelle, tels que la manipulation émotionnelle, la coercition psychologique et l'isolement social, et en expliquerons les effets sur la santé psychologique des victimes. Pour finir, au travers d'exemples, nous témoignerons du processus psychologique par lequel les membres passent et les enjeux à travailler en psychothérapie.

Forgiveness (Doug Duncan) 
-
Doug Duncan, MS, LPC, was a member of an aberrant religious group for over twenty years. After defying the cult leader and marrying Wendy, they eventually left the cult and Doug began the task of rebuilding his life. He enrolled in a master’s program in counseling and earned a degree and license to practice therapy. Marital Damage and Recovery Following Religious Abuse (Pat and Heidi Knapp) 
-

episodes.title: Panel: Pursuing Justice in the Time of COVID: KwaSizabantu as a Case Study
episodes.description:
Pursuing Justice in the Time of COVID: KwaSizabantu as a Case Study - Erika Bornman, Daniel Schricker
-
Disclaimer: This session was delivered for the 2023 ICSA Conference. The speaker of this session does not speak on behalf of ICSA as an organization.
-
Abstract: One of the challenges in the pursuit of justice in relation to abusive religious cults is galvanizing authorities into action. Using KwaSizabantu Mission in South Africa as a case study, this paper examines how ex-members involved the media and how the subsequent media exposé prompted authorities to investigate KSB, paying particular attention to the ongoing role of trauma in the lives of the survivors. It is well-documented that ongoing trauma symptoms have a direct bearing on the ability of former members to participate in legal and investigative processes to pursue justice and hold the perpetrators accountable.

The paper will give a brief overview of the childhood trauma experienced at KwaSizabantu as documented in the testimonies of survivors and the ongoing spiritual, physical, social, and psychological manifestations of childhood trauma throughout adulthood in the lives of those who have left KwaSizabantu. Using personal testimonies and video footage, we will discuss the impact of ongoing trauma, the media exposure, and investigative procedures on survivors attempting to seek justice. This will be done with a view to understanding broader ethical considerations in the handling of survivor testimonies. Specifically, the challenges of trauma-informed representation to aid survivors in speaking out will be examined in reference to the approach taken by investigative panels, the media, and KwaSizabantu itself. Because these investigations have coincided with the COVID pandemic, consideration will also be given to some of the ways in which lockdowns and restrictions mitigated or contributed to further trauma for the survivors.

episodes.title: Panel: The PsychoSocial Quicksand Model™
episodes.description:
The PsychoSocial Quicksand Model™: An Investigation Into the Efficacy of the Model for Survivors of Coercive Control and Professionals and Implications for Education and Practice - Kate Amber, Rod Dubrow-Marshall
-
Disclaimer: This session was delivered for the 2023 ICSA Conference. The speaker of this session does not speak on behalf of ICSA as an organization.
-
Abstract: The PsychoSocial Quicksand Model™ is an educational resource and toolkit designed to help survivors, families, and the public better understand the nature of coercive control in abusive relationships and groups. The research reported in this presentation is a mixed-methods investigation into the validity and effectiveness of the PSQM™ involving interviews and the completion of questionnaires. Participants (N=59) were recruited online and are a mixture of survivors of intimate partner violence, cults (both forms of coercion), and professionals in the field. Each participant watched a series of seven videos about the model and completed a series of evaluative questions about how helpful the model was to them. They also completed a series of questionnaires about their own experiences of coercive control and mental health. A subset of the participants (n=13) also volunteered to be interviewed about their experience of learning about the model. Analysis of the qualitative data indicated that the model was well received, with a broad theme reflecting core aspects of the model and a theme reflecting survivors' stories, indicating a good degree of resonance between the model and prior experiences. Quantitative analysis indicated that, with some of the model videos and questions, the survivors (some of whom were also professionals) showed greater appreciation than participants who were professionals with no survivor experiences. This is further evidence that the model reflects survivor experience and is potentially helpful to survivor recovery. Additional analysis indicates the extent to which reported levels of coercion and mental health vary according to participant group and following, as well as prior to, the watching of the model videos. There are some key implications for the further development of the PSQM™ and for education, practice, and professionals in the field that need to be disseminated more widely.

episodes.title: The Many Facets of Identity Recovery on Escaping a Cult
episodes.description:
The Many Facets of Identity Recovery on Escaping a Cult - Peter Blachly
-
Disclaimer: This session was delivered for the 2023 ICSA Conference. The speaker of this session does not speak on behalf of ICSA as an organization.
-
Abstract: In writing about my own experience thirty-five years after leaving Yogi Bhajan's cult of the American Sikhs, I have come to the conclusion that "you can take a person out of a cult, but it is much harder to take the cult out of a person," to paraphrase a common saying. Cults have a profound impact on every aspect of a person's identity and well-being, influencing their appearance, worldview, sense of agency, ethical framework, spiritual superiority, sense of shame, and more. Recovering from a cult entails reclaiming an authentic sense of identity, free from the distorted norms imposed by the cult in virtually every aspect of life. These norms are often deeply ingrained, and ex-cult members may not even be aware of their origin or their ongoing influence on their lives.

For instance, many eastern spiritual cults promote the belief in past life "karma" as a determinant of current situations, such as social status within the cult or the justification for unethical behavior, such as sexual abuse by the cult leader. Since most cults consume every aspect of a person's beliefs, attitudes, practices, and lifestyle, former members face immense challenges to their sense of identity upon leaving, and it often takes many years to confront the lingering effects of the cult.

This presentation will delve into the various factors that continue to exert destructive influence even after physically leaving a cult, providing insights into the lasting impact on individuals. Additionally, it will offer options and strategies for regaining a healthy and authentic sense of identity.

episodes.title: War Trauma Outside of War Zones
episodes.description:
War Trauma Outside of War Zones - Olivia Djouadi
-
Disclaimer: This session was delivered for the 2023 ICSA Conference. The speaker of this session does not speak on behalf of ICSA as an organization.
-
Abstract: When war breaks out, people can go through a training regime so they are ready to face the war on both sides. The skills taught can seem outrageous within a non-war situation. It can also seem at odds with human rights even within a war situation. So, one might see skills to use weapons as important but other tactics are less noted such as rape or captivity.

People are also trained how to hold people captive or rape as the other side are seen as the enemy or subhuman even if say in a civil war, they lived close to each other. Rape can bring a feeling of shame so those that experienced this are less likely to say what happened or be believed.

So, during or after the war people who are trained may go abroad and even reach places like the United Kingdom. They will use tactics they learned in or for war to use on people not within a war zone. Sometimes if a survivor escapes it will be seen as domestic violence rather than war trauma which has a different flavour. They may say all authority figures such as police, military, the court system, religion etc will shoot you if you look at them. They may describe exactly which weapon they will use. It can make life after terrifying and one feels they will get killed just being in public. They may encourage you to act in ways that don’t even make sense once away from the captivity.

So, what options do people have if they reached safety and are too scared to talk? I will also discuss what can help in the Western world.

episodes.title: Why Fear Makes Us Say "Yes" When We Knew We Should Have Said "No"
episodes.description:
Why Fear Makes Us Say "Yes" When We Knew We Should Have Said "No" - Rachel Bernstein
-
Disclaimer: This session was delivered for the 2023 ICSA Conference. The speaker of this session does not speak on behalf of ICSA as an organization.
-
Abstract: During this time of COVID, our level of fear has risen greatly. People are afraid because of the ongoing and virulent nature of this illness, as well as its unpredictability. The fact that it can be so communicable and also have a long-lasting impact has caused a sharp increase in interest in conspiratorial thinking, psychics, healers, shamans, channelers, and the like who tout magical energy cures or peddle pseudoscience and protective potions.

Simultaneously, there has been a lessening of civility and the impossibility, at times, of having a conversation about this issue without it erupting into a fight. Families and communities have been torn apart, and people have dealt with increasing isolation caused by social distancing and discord.

As we know, cult leaders and those pushing pseudoscience take advantage of these moments, providing replacement communities and preying on people's fears in order to ensnare them. This presentation will explore what causes us to say "yes" to people offering us community and protection when there is a part of us inside doubting that this is the answer. It will investigate what people can be compelled to ignore within themselves and why good and important questions remain unasked.

Abstract: Spiritual abuse is often an integral part of other experiences of harm and abuse for those in faith communities and related contexts. This paper will present some of the findings of a recent study conducted in the UK in partnership between a Christian domestic violence charity and a charity for divorced or separated clergy spouses/partners. The study focused on developing understanding and effective support for victims of domestic abuse in the Christian faith community. 199 respondents completed an online survey, of whom 69% had experienced domestic violence. Among these respondents, 60% had concurrently experienced spiritual abuse, highlighting the inter-relationship between these forms of harm. The paper will explore experiences of spiritual abuse within the context of domestic violence, including a discussion of key passages, teachings, and values identified as contributors to experiences of domestic abuse, as well as those that were seen as potentially helpful for those who have experienced this form of abuse. Importantly, it will draw on survivor suggestions for prevention, intervention, and response.

episodes.title: From the “Cult Watchers” to the “Anti-Cult Wars”
episodes.description:
From the “Cult Watchers” to the “Anti-Cult Wars” - Phil Lord
-
Disclaimer: This session was delivered for the 2023 ICSA Conference. The speaker of this session does not speak on behalf of ICSA as an organization.
-
Abstract: My presentation will discuss persistent challenges in Scientology research and the way forward. In my previous research, I analyzed the significance of expertise in grounding and justifying a religion's claim of legitimacy in the eyes of the law. I traced the emergence of CESNUR and, more broadly, a community of scholars who take a notably more favorable stance on Scientology, influencing the diversity of Scientology research. While I, like others, have criticized the rigor of their research, it will undoubtedly impact legal and political decision-makers. Building on my previous research, my presentation will explore the academic approaches and theories employed by these scholars in their analysis of Scientology. I will discuss and aim to refute their main assertion that prior to their involvement, Scientology research lacked sophistication by (1) focusing on Scientology's organizational behavior instead of its theology, beliefs, and practices, and (2) overly relying on testimonies from former members.

While it is true that previous Scientology research has sometimes failed to distinguish adequately between Scientology's beliefs and organizational behavior, there are substantive legal and analytical justifications for studying Scientology's organizational behavior. Due to the comprehensive nature of Scientology's belief and governance system, its organizational behavior is often driven by and inseparable from its theology. Focusing solely on Scientology's theology presents an incomplete and misleading portrayal. A comprehensive and accurate understanding of Scientology, on the other hand, acknowledges its differences from other religions and new religious movements.

The criticism of relying on the testimonies of former members is, although not explicitly stated, ideological and misguided. It can partly be attributed to the objection of traditional Scientology scholars to using testimonies from current members. Both objections make unsupported, sweeping claims about reliability and detract from rigorous and nuanced academic analysis.

episodes.title: Panel: Religious Fraud and Forgery
episodes.description:
Religious Fraud and Forgery - Phil Lord, Stephen Kent, Maryam Razavy
-
Disclaimer: This session was delivered for the 2023 ICSA Conference. The speaker of this session does not speak on behalf of ICSA as an organization.
-
Abstract: This presentation argues for the importance of identifying fraud and forgery as analytical categories for the study of religion when examining data from the ancient world into the contemporary period. It builds upon the foundational work of Arthur J. Droge, a scholar of Hebrew Bible/Old Testament, and Bart D. Ehrman, a New Testament scholar, both of whom wrote about fraud and forgery in the ancient world. The discussion then expands to include a wide range of religions throughout history, including several contemporary sects, cults, and/or 'new religions.'

While the focus of work on the ancient world is primarily on textual frauds and forgeries, a broader examination of religion encompasses fraudulent artifacts and both embellished and falsified religious credentials. Recent analyses of criminal acts emphasize the prevalence of religiously based affinity fraud. Many of these frauds and forgeries challenge the legitimacy and authority claims made by religious leaders and their followers, and some have had significant social, legal, and political impacts.

Maryam Razavy will present a basic introduction to the topic of religious fraud, followed by a discussion of examples from major religious traditions. Stephen Kent will then extend the discussion to modern examples within sectarian groups. Phil Lord will conclude the presentation with a discussion of the legal treatment of religious fraud, highlighting several important cases.

episodes.title: After They Leave: Post-Exit Distress and Coping in Former Extremists
episodes.description:
After They Leave: Post-Exit Distress and Coping in Former Extremists - Katharina Meredith
-
Disclaimer: This session was delivered for the 2023 ICSA Conference. The speaker of this session does not speak on behalf of ICSA as an organization.
-
Abstract: Violent extremism is a growing worldwide problem that has received increased attention over the last twenty years, resulting in the advancement of knowledge on how people join, their involvement, and how they leave. An understudied area is people’s experiences after they have left and are trying to reintegrate into mainstream society. Practitioners are often unequipped to assist in this transition, and tools are lacking to assess former extremists' psychosocial well-being and practical needs.

Katharina Meredith, who studies violent extremism with Dr. John Horgan at Georgia State University, will present the findings of her Master’s thesis on post-exit distress and coping. For the study, practitioners and former extremists were recruited for focus groups and interviews. A reflexive thematic analysis was used to summarize the topics and explore underlying themes. This resulted in an exploratory framework of post-exit distress and coping. Additionally, participants were invited back to provide feedback on the findings.

The post-exit distress framework includes dimensions such as mental health, emotions, physical health, daily life, legal matters, social relationships, exit and reintegration, safety, public image, identity, and worldview.

This exploratory study will lead to the development of a questionnaire and a follow-up study comparing former violent extremists and former cult members regarding post-exit distress and coping. Some of the themes found might already apply to former cult members, including "feeling wired" (hypervigilance and the need to regulate stress levels after exiting), feeling disconnected from oneself and others, and the destabilizing nature of the initial years after leaving, characterized by internal and external chaos and uncertainty.

episodes.title: Reproductive Coercion, Psychologically Abusive Environments, and the Extent of Group Identity
episodes.description:
The Relationship Between Reproductive Coercion, Psychologically Abusive Environments, and the Extent of Group Identity in a Sample of Those Who Have Left Cultic Groups - Ashlen Hilliard 
-
Disclaimer: This session was delivered for the 2023 ICSA Conference. The speaker of this session does not speak on behalf of ICSA as an organization.
-
Abstract: Ashlen Hilliard (she/her) will present her research conducted as part of the MSc Psychology of Coercive Control Program. Reproductive coercion interferes with an individual's rights and freedoms related to reproductive health decisions and decision-making to maintain power and control over the individual and prevent autonomy (Grace & Anderson, 2018). The accounts of those in cultic groups who experience a lack of reproductive autonomy are vital when reviewing existing definitions surrounding reproductive coercion. Existing understandings in the literature on reproductive coercion highlight that this particular form of coercion may be perpetrated by current or former intimate relationships, parents, or extended familial relationships (Grace & Anderson, 2018). However, in the context of those in cultic groups, the source of reproductive coercion may extend beyond an intimate relationship or family member. Potential sources of influence that may disrupt reproductive autonomy in cultic groups may include but are not limited to, the presence of a cult leader, cultural factors, or group ideological beliefs. Ashlen’s research is the first exploratory analysis of the complex experiences of individuals who have experienced reproductive coercion while under the influence of a cultic or destructive group setting. Her research fills an identifiable gap in the literature by specifically studying how reproductive coercion manifests in destructive group settings, which has only been anecdotally alluded to from survivor accounts.

episodes.title: What Causes Awe Experiences
episodes.description:
What Causes Awe Experiences - Yuval Laor 
-
Disclaimer: This session was delivered for the 2023 ICSA Conference. The speaker of this session does not speak on behalf of ICSA as an organization.
-
Abstract: The lecture will start with a short review of previous lectures I gave about the nature of awe and the relationship between awe and the psychological state of fervor. What I didn't discuss previously is the counterintuitive subject of the causes of awe.

The most confusing aspect of awe experiences is that a person who experiences them can easily mistake what actually caused the experience with the conclusion that the person thinks the experience proves. For example, if a person sees a glass of water start to levitate, they might be filled with awe and conclude that a deity is sending them a message. What actually caused the awe experience is the levitating glass of water, but if you were to ask the person, they are likely to say that it was the presence of the deity that caused the glass to levitate, while the awe experience would just be seen as a side-effect.

I will argue that awe comes about when people judge something as being sufficiently anomalous. Note that central to this claim is a person's judgment, meaning that there is nothing that is inherently awe-inspiring. It also means that almost anything can be thought of in a way that inspires awe. I will pay particular attention to the relationship between the causes and effects of awe and the sense of vastness (which is related to the vestibular sense, which has an interesting relationship with awe).

By understanding the causes of awe, we can see how people can be manipulated to feel awe, and more importantly, how cults can make sure that the potential recruit that they induce awe in comes to the "correct" conclusion. After all, a levitating glass of water can psychologically "prove" any faith.

episodes.title: Identity Fusion and Extreme Pro-Group Behavior in Members of Abusive Groups
episodes.description:
Identity Fusion and Extreme Pro-Group Behavior in Members of Abusive Groups - Almudena Tello, Omar Saldaña, Irene Sánchez, Álvaro Rodríguez-Carballeira
-
Disclaimer: This session was delivered for the 2023 ICSA Conference. The speaker(s) of this session does not speak on behalf of ICSA as an organization.
-
Abstract: In recent years, the theory of identity fusion has been proposed to explain extreme behaviors conducted by people on behalf of a greater good, such as a group or a cause. This means that when individuals feel a sense of oneness with a group, they tend to prioritize the group's goals over their own well-being. Evidence has shown that strongly fused individuals are more likely to endorse extreme pro-group behaviors, such as being willing to fight for the group, volunteer for frontline combat, sacrifice their own lives, engage in morally questionable actions in support of the group, or accept violence in general. Researchers have explored the level of fusion individuals experience with various groups, including their country, sacred values, the military, their families, or political parties, among others. They have also studied how this fusion affects individuals' willingness to make costly sacrifices and engage in extreme behaviors in violent contexts, such as hooliganism and terrorism.

Initially, it was hypothesized that abusive (or cultic) group members would have high levels of fusion. However, no empirical research to date has explored the role of this phenomenon in cults. The purpose of this study is to investigate how identity fusion with a group influences individuals not only to tolerate the abuse of other group members but also to have an inclination or willingness to perpetrate such abuse, particularly if they have previously been victims of it. To achieve this goal, we will compare how these phenomena manifest in both abusive and non-abusive religious groups. We expect to obtain results that help us better understand the violent dynamics that occur in cultic groups and may provide insights into whether it is necessary to implement certain strategies to reduce individuals' identity fusion in order to prevent group members from acting in ways that are unjust, illegal, or harmful to themselves or others.

episodes.title: Corpus, Habitus & Abuses in Religious Environment: A Debate on Cultural Identity & Victims’ Silence
episodes.description:
Corpus, Habitus and Abuses in Religious Environment: A Debate on Cultural Identity and Victims’ Silence - Tatiana Badaro
-
Disclaimer: This session was delivered for the 2023 ICSA Conference. The speaker of this session does not speak on behalf of ICSA as an organization.
-
Abstract: It is widely reported by Brazilian media the recurrence of abuses perpetrated by alleged religious leaders against their followers. Unfortunately, many of the cases find obstacles in the legal process itself due to a lack of technical information from the magistrates involved. This serious problem, which is a new violence against victims of undue influence, would be easily circumvented if a specialized analysis were requested to assist judges in their decisions.

While Brazilian attention focuses on victimology to explain the phenomenon, it is important to discuss the modus operandi of groups based on undue influence. These groups reproduce the social imaginary that the collective is always right, leading to the logical conclusion that any negative result is attributed to a single subject. However, culture is formed by a broad corpus that implies a habitus that can lead to absurdities. In other words, it is not possible for a single person to be responsible for a social phenomenon such as Bolsonarism.

Bringing this reflection to the logic of victimology in cults of undue influence, it is not the victim who should suffer socio-legal scrutiny, but the group that perpetrated the violence. This leads to one more issue: there is a support network for the abusive leader that needs to be addressed at the academic and legal level.

This talk aims to debate Brazilian cultural identity that favors the silencing of victims and protects criminals, highlighting laws concerning cases of undue influence in religious environments. This study is part of a post-doctoral research at the Federal University of Bahia. The methodological course involved a broad bibliographic review about undue influence in religious circles, as well as documentary analysis of judicial decisions and cases shared by the Public Ministry of five Brazilian states in which the investigated processes took place.

episodes.title: Toward a Model of Interpersonal Domination to Understand Violence Perpetrated in Close Relationships
episodes.description:
Towards a Model of Interpersonal Domination to Understand Violence Perpetrated in Close Relationships - Omar Saldaña, Carolina Andana, Almudena Tello, Álvaro Rodríguez-Carballeira
-
Disclaimer: This session was delivered for the 2023 ICSA Conference. The speaker of this session does not speak on behalf of ICSA as an organization.
-
Abstract: In recent years, scientific evidence has accumulated on the elements that characterize different forms of interpersonal violence that can occur in intense, continuous, close relationships. The purpose of this study was to examine the similarities that exist between violence perpetrated in abusive groups, intimate partner violence, and the sexual exploitation of children and adolescents. First, these forms of interpersonal violence involve a severe power imbalance between a victim who is usually in a situation of vulnerability and a perpetrator who holds some kind of authority. This power imbalance makes victims relatively unable to defend their own interests and feel increasingly powerless, helpless, and even more vulnerable. Second, the recurrence and duration of interactions over time are key elements to understand the phenomenon. Violence is perpetrated on a continuous and systematic basis, which allows the process to be gradually intensified and fosters the normalization of the abusive situation. Third, interpersonal violence involves the implementation of a wide range of psychological, sexual, and physical abuse strategies that directly impact the victims by affecting their emotions, cognitions, and behaviors, or indirectly by controlling their immediate environment. Scholars have identified several strategies that can be perpetrated against cult followers, women in couples, and sexually exploited minors alike, such as isolation, intimidation and threats, manipulation of guilt, or the redefinition of reality. Fourth, the primary goal of interpersonal violence in close relationships is to obtain submission and broad dominance over the lives of the victims, rather than to cause damage or simply obtain obedience to specific orders. For perpetrators, domination may produce satisfaction associated with the achievement of power, as well as other benefits related to the labor, economic, or sexual exploitation of the victims. A conceptual model that highlights the parallelisms between these forms of interpersonal violence may be useful to better understand the phenomenon.

Abstract: In today's age of domestic abuse awareness, this topic has been heavily studied and researched. We understand the patterns and tactics of the abusers themselves. This helps us to identify risks and prevent harm to women and children, affecting families and society at large. This presentation seeks to uncover what we might learn about the lesser studied realm of cults by exploring similarities between abusive intimate partners and cult leaders. The invisible thread that binds the two is revealed. Parallels and insights into the patterns of the abusers themselves help us detect who is safe, who is not, and how to protect ourselves and those we love from harmful individuals.

For the Love of God: A Phenomenological Study Exploring the Lived Experiences and the Impact of the Belief System of the Jehovah’s Witnesses Students Enrolled at Secular Higher Education Institutions - Michael O. Miller

Abstract: The focus of this proposed phenomenological study is to explore the lived experiences of Jehovah's Witnesses (JW) students enrolled at secular higher education institutions and how the JW organization, along with its doctrines, impacts their collegiate experiences. A historical perspective of the JW organization, including its religious belief system, is presented to provide context for the proposed study. The study aims to answer three research questions: (1) What are the lived experiences of Jehovah's Witnesses students who attend secular higher education institutions? (2) How do the Jehovah's Witnesses organization and its doctrines impact the experiences of Jehovah's Witnesses students attending secular higher education institutions? (3) How can educators help incorporate and support Jehovah's Witnesses students in secular higher education institutions?

The research questions will be addressed by conducting a series of three semi-structured interviews (Seidman, 2019) with five JW student participants who meet the sample criteria. Additionally, document analysis will be conducted on the JW organization's Watchtower Bible and Tract Society magazines and pamphlets, Awake and Watchtower. This proposed research study aims to contribute to the limited published research on JW students at secular higher education institutions and provide valuable insights for JW students making decisions about student services and programs. It also offers recommendations, strategies, and resources to educators and administrators seeking to support JW students.

episodes.title: Sexual Violence in Group Contexts
episodes.description:
Sexual Violence in Cultic Group Contexts: How Sexual Violence Is Perceived During and After Group Involvement - Marie-Andrée Pelland, Celeste Goguen
-
Disclaimer: This session was delivered for the 2023 ICSA Conference. The speaker of this session does not speak on behalf of ICSA as an organization.
-
Abstract: Sexual violence is an experience of victimization shared by numerous North Americans. In the United States, one in five women and one in four men have been victims of attempted rape or rape during their lifetime (Smith et al., 2018). In a victimization survey, data shows that 81% of women and 43% of men recognize that they have experienced some form of sexual harassment and assault. In Canada, 39% of women and 35% of men have been sexually assaulted. Additionally, one in three (32%) women and one in eight (13%) men have experienced unwanted sexual behavior in public (Cotter and Savage, 2019). These statistics help us recognize that sexual violence is gender-based, and women are more likely than men to experience unwanted sexual violence in their lifetime. This can include diverse forms of sexual violence, from sexual harassment to sexual assault (Kelly, 1988).

What is the situation of sexual violence in cultic contexts? Is this also a gender-based form of control? Is unwanted sexual behavior within a cultic group a reality as well? Can members freely give their sexual consent? How do members perceive behaviors that could be interpreted as sexual violence by outsiders? At what point in their trajectory does a former member recognize that what he or she experienced can be described as sexual violence?

To address these questions, we will analyze qualitative data from two sources: interviews and biographies. We will analyze thirty interviews with members and former members from various North American groups to comprehend their understanding of sexual violence within their community and their own experiences. To further our understanding, we will include former members' biographies, where they identified themselves as victims of sexual violence. Our results will aim to understand how sexual violence can be defined as a form of control over women's bodies.

episodes.title: Cultic Tendencies Within Denominational Churches: A Case Study of the Church of England
episodes.description:
Cultic Tendencies Within Denominational Churches: A Case Study of the Church of England - Stephen Parsons
-
Disclaimer: This session was delivered for the 2023 ICSA Conference. The speaker of this session does not speak on behalf of ICSA as an organization.
-
Abstract: This talk will explore three ways in which certain cultic strands have started to appear within a denominational church, the Church of England, in recent years. As a summary, I will give each of these three named cultic tendencies a two-word description - Binary Thinking, Narcissistic Exchange, and Artificial Community.

1. Binary Thinking: Parts of the Church of England have increasingly aligned themselves with fundamentalist/binary ways of thinking. This black-white fundamentalist universe does not encourage imagination, wonder, or a sense of mystery. As a result, many CofE members are now deprived of spiritual creativity and the opportunity to deal with ambiguity and doubt.

2. Narcissistic Exchange: There is an increasing tendency for CofE Christians to flock to large churches that require them to identify with and pour adulation on charismatic leaders. These leaders create a sense of power and excitement around them. On closer examination, we find a narcissistic bond between leaders and followers. This narcissistic feeding works in two directions. Leaders are encouraged in their grandiosity by uncritical worship of their charisma, while those who follow are fed with reassuring sermons about their salvation. However, there is little face-to-face pastoral support, and this narcissistic interdependency is ultimately unhealthy and sterile.

3. Artificial Community: The need to belong is a strong motivation for people coming together. The community life offered by many "successful" churches is strong on providing a sense of security and comfort but weak in addressing the true demands of maturity. Maturity encompasses conflict resolution and learning to live in a way that embraces differences.

The paper will conclude with a visual examination of church websites that illustrate each of these cultic tendencies.

episodes.title: Practicing Medicine Without a License: Neo-Exorcism and the Deliverance Movement in America
episodes.description:
Practicing Medicine Without a License: Neo-Exorcism and the Deliverance Movement in America - Anna Kitko
-
Disclaimer: This session was delivered for the 2023 ICSA Conference. The speaker of this session does not speak on behalf of ICSA as an organization.
-
The resurgence of the cult of Simon Magus has found footing in the form of "Deliverance Ministries" across the country, but particularly in the Appalachian mountain areas. These groups intertwine pseudo-psychiatric treatments popular in the 1970s, such as Neuro-Linguistic Programming and hypnotherapy, with existing treatments for Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder. Practitioners claim that these treatments exorcise demonic presences in the lives of their clients. The overlay of Christian-based loaded language, combined with the popularity of current theological movements like the charismatic movement, helps fuel and create an environment for these practitioners to attempt to practice medicine without a license and prey upon victims of religious trauma who are seeking healing in those same charismatic Christian environments.

This paper will explore the forensic theological history of deliverance movements, their predominance in Appalachian mountain culture, their usage of manipulative psychotherapy frameworks disguised as punctuated exorcisms, an analysis of the clinical outcomes for individuals caught in the lucrative financial engine that these groups have designed, and recommendations for treatment and best practices for practitioners who are treating victims of these groups.

episodes.title: How Do Cults and Authoritarian Systems Promise Us Meaning and Connection but Deliver Stress
episodes.description:
How Do Cults and Authoritarian Systems Promise Us Meaning and Connection but Deliver Stress and Intensity? - Ron Burks
-
Disclaimer: This session was delivered for the 2023 ICSA Conference. The speaker of this session does not speak on behalf of ICSA as an organization.
-
The aim of this presentation is to introduce attendees to a few of the chemicals, hormones, and neurotransmitters in the brain collectively referred to as the "me" chemicals and the "we" chemicals. Experiencing a high-demand, closed environment alters the subtle balance between them, thereby altering how the brain processes emotions and information.

By providing experiences that overly focus on the "What" and "How" of life but suppress the "Why" or meaning-making, our "me" chemicals are activated, and we feel somewhat fulfilled. However, we lack the necessary opportunities to activate the "we" chemicals, and we constantly feel like we are falling short of what is expected. This presentation is not a scientific paper but is intended to foster growth by providing yet another perspective from which to understand cult experiences and recovery.

These restrictions, however, have been progressively modified over the past twenty years. In this presentation, we will discuss the ways in which this group adapted during the COVID-19 pandemic, including how their stance toward modern technology underwent further alteration. Abstract: Through qualitative research, my study addresses the inadequate amount of research investigating the educational identity formation of individuals who are raised as Jehovah's Witnesses (JW). Narratives from semi-structured interviews suggest that participants negotiated multiple identities in multiple frames—their identity as religious members and their personal educational identity in secular education. Abstract: In 2023, Info-Cult will celebrate 43 years of serving the public! Founded in Montreal (Quebec, Canada) in 1980, Info-Cult is a non-profit charitable organization that offers information and assistance about groups—their ideology, functioning, and interpersonal relationships. The proposed presentation will provide an overview of Info-Cult regarding its conceptualization of religious, new religious, and cultic movements. The presenters will discuss the circumstances surrounding the creation of the organization and how the conceptualization of the cult phenomenon has evolved over time. They will also highlight how the organization has developed a viewpoint that goes beyond labels such as cults, new religious movements, extremist groups, radical groups, and coercive groups, in order to support people in understanding their experiences in a given group. episodes.title: Describing and Understanding Women's Experiences in Cultic Groups
episodes.description:
Describing and Understanding Women's Experiences in Cultic Groups - Andrea Lagorse
-
Disclaimer: This session was delivered for the 2023 ICSA Conference. The speaker of this session does not speak on behalf of ICSA as an organization.
-
This talk will present the results of my master's thesis, which focuses on the specific experiences of women in a cultic context. Only a few studies have been carried out on this subject. Nevertheless, it seems that the cultic context provides an opportunity for leaders and the groups they have created to use psychological and sexual violence against women. Violence, gender inequalities, power relations, and stigmatization that women have suffered for decades in society are found in cultic contexts. These groups often maintain a patriarchal system that views women as inferior to men. It, therefore, seems relevant to look at women's experiences in cultic groups, especially in the Canadian social context, where women's rights are a central concern.

The main objective of this thesis was to identify the experiences of girls and women in cultic groups, with an emphasis on experiences of victimization, if applicable, based on the testimony of former members of such groups.

Using a qualitative methodology, eight in-depth life-story interviews were conducted with female former cult members. The participants' testimonies were analyzed from a feminist perspective, based on Stark's (2007) theory of coercive control.

The presented results show that women are subject to coercive control by the leader, which is reinforced by other members and sometimes by family members involved in the group. Participants are locked into roles that often stem from a patriarchal vision of women's place in society, forcing them to respond to the requirements of the leader and the community to whicxh they belong. Women also encounter difficulties when they leave the group, particularly in relation to seeking formal help. Considering the collected data, there is a real need for awareness, training, and research on understanding the specific cultic experiences of women to help them while respecting what they have experienced.

episodes.title: The Anti-Cult Movement in Russia
episodes.description:
The Anti-Cult Movement in Russia - Dan Phillips, Tommy Valentine
-
Disclaimer: This session was delivered for the 2023 ICSA Conference. The speaker of this session does not speak on behalf of ICSA as an organization.
-
Abstract: "Anti-cult" groups began to form in the 1970s in the United States in response to the perceived destructive nature of various new religious movements (NRM) (also known pejoratively as "cults") that flourished in the 1960s. Parents, family members, and professionals of cults/NRM have since debated how cults/NRM should be viewed by society. Some have seen cults/NRM as destructive, and their members in need of saving through the use of techniques such as "deprogramming." However, there have been others who view the countermovement anti-cult groups as more destructive than those in the NRM themselves.

Since the fall of the Soviet Union in the early 1990s, various parties in Russia have fought for legislation to ban religious groups that are seen as dangerous. The Russians have enacted legislation to prohibit various religious groups, such as the Jehovah's Witnesses, who were banned from Russia in 2017. Alexander Dvorkin has been on the frontline in the anti-cult movement in Russia. He is concerned that there exist destructive cults in Russia that attempt to control every aspect of their members' lives. Dvorkin wants individuals to have rights stronger than the rights of specific religious groups.

This presentation examines the post-Soviet anti-cult movement, the philosophy behind it, along with the major individuals and groups who are driving the anti-cult agenda. The Russian Orthodox Church, for instance, has supported the anti-cult movement, but there are other factors involved, not the least of which is Putin's desire to have the population united by one religion. Finally, Russia's anti-cult movement will be examined in the context of the Western anti-cult movement that occurred in the 1970s and 1980s in the United States.

episodes.description:
You Should Write a Memoir! - Nori Muster

Disclaimer: This session was delivered for the 2023 ICSA Conference. The speaker of this session does not speak on behalf of ICSA as an organization.
-
Abstract: In 1997, Nori Muster published "Betrayal of the Spirit," a memoir about her ten years with the Hare Krishnas. For most of those years, she participated in covering up the organization's secrets. When she realized what was going on, she signed up for the UCLA Extension Writer's Program to learn how to tell the story. By the time she left the temple, she had a five-hundred-page doorstop of a manuscript. The final book was 213 pages.

Nori has been writing for publication since 1981 and will share what she's learned. The subjects include: how to decide what story you want to tell, what to include or leave out, the importance of your working title, how to obey slander and libel laws, where to seek feedback, when not to talk about your work, how to manage writer's block, whether to join a writing group or class, whether to publish, whether to self-publish, how to self-publish, how to write a memoir for future generations of your family, whether to use a pseudonym, how to choose a title, how to write a book proposal, and how to work with an agent or publisher.

Nori will present the information first and then open a group discussion. If you have ideas for writing a memoir or you're already in the process, this workshop will address your concerns. This workshop is designed to be inspirational, to help you get past the obstacles and on the road.

Your goal may or may not include publishing, but simply putting your memories on paper is therapeutic because it helps get them out of your head. Reading and editing what you write helps you process your experiences. After the discussion, Nori will lead a writing exercise to brainstorm a title for your memoir.

Abstract: My presentation will be about the troubled teen industry and its use of coercive control and thought reform as a form of "treatment". This industry, which is mostly unregulated and unlicensed, manipulates desperate parents into thinking they will save children who are struggling with serious issues, including but not limited to trauma, neglect, learning disabilities, and severe mental health diagnoses. This industry utilizes coercive control and meets the same criteria as thought reform groups developed by Robert Jay Lifton. The aftermath for these children is devastating. Mental health professionals are often not trained in how to treat the survivors of this industry, and they just do not seem to fit in anywhere among survivor communities, or in the worst case, they unknowingly send clients to these programs for "treatment". However, there is growing awareness through advocacy groups, and I'd like to educate the cult community on how these survivors fit into the cult community and give them a voice and a place to belong. As a survivor of this industry and a mental health professional who is very passionate about working with cult survivors, I am excited to present this issue to my colleagues at the International Conference.

Domestic abuse is now recognized as a widespread social problem   It is estimated that nearly half of all women and men will experience interpersonal aggression in a familial context during their lifetimes. This talk will suggest a connection between the power dynamic of domestic abuse, or as it is now often called, interpersonal violence, and the dynamic of coercive control in cultic groups. episodes.title: Generation Cult: Using New Media to Share Your Story
episodes.description:
Generation Cult: Using New Media to Share Your Story (Dhyana Levey)

Presentation at the International Cultic Studies Association annual conference in Manchester, UK in 2019. The public loves a good story and is especially interested in true tales about cults. Unfortunately, there’s a lot of inaccurate information floating around about these high-demand, authoritarian groups. That’s why it’s so important for people who have had personal experiences with a variety of cults to share their stories. So, how does someone do that? Traditionally, writers have published books. Some are lucky enough to get a legitimate publisher, but that can be difficult, even more so now as that publishing industry has been in decline. But there are many other options now for people to share their stories. The internet and social media have become a very effective way to share information about cults, from online support groups to personal blogs to a simple confession on Facebook shared with your friends. Podcasts are an excellent way to learn about cults. There’s one just called “Cults,” another called “We’re Starting a Cult,” podcasts that just focus on a single cult like “Heaven’s Gate” and then there’s my own called “Generation Cult,” that discusses people raised in high-demand groups. At first I thought traditional publishing was the only way to get my message to the public, but I learned how to make my own podcast and it wasn’t that hard. Other people can do it, too. There are plenty of creative options out there now for former cult members to use to share their stories, they just have to know how to use them.

episodes.title: Developing the ‘Totalistic Identity Theory’
episodes.description:
Developing the ‘Totalistic Identity Theory’ for cults and extremist groups
(Rod Dubrow-Marshall, Ph.D.)

Research previously presented (Dubrow-Marshall and Martin 2008) has articulated the ‘Totalistic Identity Theory’ for cultic and extremist groups whereby it is advanced that members identity structures are largely dominated and fixed on the cult identity at the expense of many or all other levels and categories of identity and in a polarized or differentiated position in relation to other groups and society at large. This theory (Dubrow-Marshall 2007) is an extension of traditional social psychological theory on group identity (e.g. Turner’s (1987) Self-Categorization Theory). Analysis of former cult members from the Wellspring Retreat and Resource Center in Ohio (Dubrow-Marshall & Martin 2008) has also shown a clear relationship between aspects of psychopathology and extent of identity with the group, thus providing evidence that a totalistic or polarized identity structure is harmful for group members.
This paper presents further analysis from the Wellspring sample advancing further a model for the specific psychopathology of former cult members. This analysis points to additional evidence for the ‘Totalistic Identity Theory’ and in particular aspects relating to the polarized identity position and its relationship to overall psychological well being and the perception by current group members of non-group members and the rest of the world and the behavioural correlates of such perceptions. The theory also points to and supports strategies for depolarization and de-identification with extremist groups and approaches to preventing initial recruitment to them.

episodes.title: Religious Conflict Resolution
episodes.description:
Religious Conflict Resolution (Michael Langone, PhD.) 

Research suggests that, in the West, hundreds of thousands of individuals join and leave
cultic groups each year. Research studies also suggest that at least a sizable minority of
those who join cultic groups are adversely affected. The families of these group members,
and probably many other families, tend to become concerned about their loved one‘s group
involvement.
Roughly 80 percent of the groups that cause concern are religious. The psychological,
political, and occasionally commercial groups that aren‘t overtly religious often influence
members‘ lives as though they were religions because they typically bring about a major
shift in members‘ views of self, world, and other—i.e., a conversion experience.
During the past 25 years, most professionals who work with these families have emphasized
helping them persuade their loved ones to leave cultic groups. Exit counseling, a process
aimed at helping families create conditions under which their loved one will reevaluate a
group involvement, has been very valuable to thousands of grateful families and group
members. (Exit counseling is also often referred to as ―thought reform consultation.‖)

Nevertheless, only a very small percentage of families are able to proceed to an exit-
counseling intervention. In many cases, an intervention is not possible or even appropriate

because the loved one‘s relationship to a group does not fit the typical pattern of
exploitative manipulation associated with the subjects of exit-counseling interventions, even
though the family may have valid concerns. In other cases, the loved one may be so
attached to the group (e.g., because of family ties within the group, decades of
commitment, fear of adjusting to the mainstream world) that his or her departure is
unlikely, even with an intervention.
Very little attention has been paid to this large majority of families for whom an exit
counseling is not feasible or appropriate. Livia Bardin‘s book, Coping with Cult Involvement:
A Handbook for Families and Friends, offers some guidance. Ms. Bardin says that a cult
involvement is often ―a situation to manage, not a problem to solve.‖
This talk will explore ways in which families can more effectively ―manage‖ a loved one‘s
involvement in a group that causes concern, at least in part because of the nature of the
conversion that it tends to bring about. The talk will approach the situation as a family
conflict over what at least overtly are religious issues. Through lecture and discussion, the
speakers, a counseling psychologist, an educational/organizational consultant, and an exit
counselor (thought-reform consultant), will examine
- How families and group members can come to better understand and appreciate
each other‘s perspectives on the conflict that divides them.
- How they can improve communication so as to reduce the level of conflict.
- How they can negotiate mutual behavioral changes that will reduce the level of
conflict.
- How they can come to terms with the need to compromise so as to protect the love
between them while respecting differences that divide them.

episodes.title: Reawakening Your Spirituality After a Cult Experience
episodes.description:
Reawakening Your Spirituality After a Cult Experience
(Doug and Wendy Duncan)

Presentation at the International Cultic Studies Association annual conference in Philadelphia, PA in 2018. Spiritual abuse is widespread and can be found in all religions. Cultic/spiritual abuse occurs when leaders use their position of authority to manipulate, control, and dominate. The cult leader portrays himself as the truth-bearer and members are led to believe that God has specifically chosen him to bring light into the world. The cult leader’s claim that God has given him a unique and special revelation justifies his role as the leader and his right to exercise control over his members. Followers are taught to accept the leader’s authority as divinely mandated. In whatever manner the abusive leader uses God, karma, salvation, the threat of damnation, the promise of enlightenment, or other spiritual promises/threats, the result is the same: spiritual abuse. Any doubts or questions are quickly extinguished by the leader utilizing intimidation, humiliation, and fear. Over time, the devotee adopts the cult’s view of God and has difficulty leaving because of the fear that doing so means they are leaving “The Truth” and even God himself. When an individual manages to separate from a cultic or spiritually abusive group, he faces myriad issues of a physical and psychological nature. Defining and reclaiming post-cult spirituality is often postponed while the individual sorts through day-to-day life outside the cult. However, acknowledging the damage and recapturing one’s spiritual identity is a core task of recovery. How can we reawaken our spirituality? How do we fill that emptiness of the soul? How do we get past the feelings of confusion and disillusionment? How do we recapture a sense of purpose? This presentation will focus on:
 
Obstacles in transitioning out of a spiritually manipulative group/religion 
Expunging the image of the god of the cult 
Recovering your faith 
Reconnecting with your spiritual self”

episodes.title: Christian Cults and the Concept of Hell
episodes.description:
Christian Cults and the Concept of Hell (Robert Pardon, Michael Langone)

The inculcation of fear is a control tactic that is commonly observed in cultic groups. Those that are ostensibly Christian will often use threats of hell as one means of instilling fear designed to strengthen leaders’ hold on group members. Though most mainstream Christians accept the concept of hell, cultic groups distort and misapply the concept. Frequently, those who leave cultic Christian groups can benefit by understanding how mainstream Christians conceive of hell and how cultic groups use hell as a control tactic. This panel will explore: (1) Historical and cultural contexts that may contribute to cultic formulations of hell (e.g., Dante’s Inferno, what we would today consider inhumane punishments for misdeeds). (2) Contemporary ideas about hell that are inconsistent with cultic views. (3) Cases of former cult members whose recovery involved a reevaluation of the views of hell that resulted from their group experience.

episodes.title: Plenary: We Disagree - Let's Talk!: Why Diversity and Dialogue are Necessary
episodes.description:
Plenary: We Disagree - Let's Talk!: Why Diversity and Dialogue are Necessary (Lorna Goldberg)

Presentation at the International Cultic Studies Association annual conference in Philadelphia, PA in 2018. Unlike closed cult groups, ICSA firmly is committed to freedom of thought and expression. ICSA conferences provide an open arena for people from different backgrounds with diverse points of view. The speaker believes, in general, that dealing with conflicting viewpoints can be a healthy phenomenon. Dialogue expands our reality by helping us gain new insight into others as well as ourselves. In this presentation, the speaker will consider some factors that undermine ICSA’s goal for dialogue among diverse groups and will suggest some ideas that might help members to connect. To understand the undermining factors, the speaker will focus upon the concept of transference and, also, upon the human tendency to stereotype those from groups that are different from their own. The speaker suggests that we should not let our expectation of others shape our reality. It is only possible to hear and learn from one another if there is a willingness to move past our assumptions. It helps to keep in mind the need to be humble, remembering that all are equals deserving of respect.

episodes.title: "All Life is Suffering" - Cultic Tendencies and Student Abuse in Buddhism
episodes.description:
Panel: All Life is Suffering - Cultic Tendencies and Student Abuse in Buddhism (Christopher Hamacher [moderator]; Stuart Lachs; Tenzin Peljor)

Presentation at the International Cultic Studies Association annual conference in Bordeaux, FR in 2017. This panel will attempt to cast a more realistic light on some of the less positive elements within the religion of Buddhism, which as a whole still tends to enjoy an unblemished, "warm and fuzzy" standing in the public imagination. 

1. Ready to Mine: Zen’s Legitimating Mythology and Cultish Behavior. Long-time practitioner and outspoken critic of Zen Buddhism Stuart Lachs will show how Zen's legitimating story and mythic history lays the groundwork for authoritarian-inclined charismatic leaders ‒ called "Zen masters" or roshi ‒ to draw their followers into a world based on unquestioning obedience to the master, reliance on his approval, and an ethical framework dependent on his self-serving understanding. Though Zen presents its idealized masters as being fully in the world, spontaneous, and ‒ most importantly ‒ "unattached", a state in which they are internally firm and free while remaining perceptually competent, this has hardly been the case in reality. Stuart will accordingly provide a number of examples of Asian and Western Zen masters who, along with their followers, have displayed cult-like behavior. Link to blog: https://buddhism-controversy-blog.com/2017/07/16/ready-to-mine-zens-legitimating-mythology-and-cultish-behavior/  

2. Tibetan Buddhist monk Tenzin Peljor will explain how doctrinal issues and cross-cultural misunderstandings, for example about the concepts of faith and the guru in Tibetan Buddhism, can contribute to abusive spiritual systems. His review will begin with the highly controversial "New Kadampa Tradition" and his own experiences with that movement, and then expand to other groups. Having run an online information portal about controversial Buddhist groups for many years, Tenzin can draw on numerous examples of suspect behavior from across the broad Buddhist spectrum. Link to PowerPoint: https://tenzinpeljor.de/PDF/ICSA2017.pdf 

3. How Zen Groups Respond to Allegations of Abuse. Zen teacher Christopher Hamacher will compare various Zen Buddhist groups from the perspective of how they have responded to abuse by their teachers. Based on a number of recent scandals, he will demonstrate how various Buddhist doctrines are invoked by the leaders and students, firstly to deny the abuse and/or refuse to intervene, and afterwards to deal "compassionately" ‒ i.e ineffectively ‒ with the abuser. Christopher will then propose that, ultimately, the way a group reacts to allegations of misconduct may be a better indicator of its underlying dysfunction than the content of the allegations themselves.

episodes.title: Spiritual Issues in Counseling
episodes.description:
Spiritual Issues in Counseling (Rev. Robert Pardon; Judy Pardon)
2017

Some apply the term spiritual abuse to any kind of psychological, physical, or sexual abuse that takes place in a religious context.  Others apply the term specifically to manipulations that damage a person's relationship to God or to his/her core self. Spiritual abuse has been reported in mainstream religious organizations as well as nonmainstream groups, such as cults.

The terms psychological abuse or emotional abuse refer to harms that overlap those associated with both of these conceptualizations of spiritual abuse. These harms include but are not limited to damaged self-esteem, induced dependency, impaired capacity to trust oneself or others, and emotional reactions such as anger, anxiety, and depression. In some cases, one's faith in God may also be shaken.

To a large degree, the choice of a term, psychological abuse or spiritual abuse, depends upon the framework (psychological or religious) with which the speaker/writer feels comfortable. This two-day conference finds value in resources coming from psychological and religious frameworks, though obviously some issues, e.g., questions about God's mercy, may require religious concepts to address properly. The conference is aimed at those who were spiritually abused, whether recently or in the past, family members concerned about a loved one, and helping professionals, including pastors and therapists.

The agenda will include the following topics:

The varieties of abuse
Coping with triggers
Personal accounts of spiritual abuse
Psychological issues in counseling
Spiritual issues in counseling
How can churches and synagogues become spiritual safe havens
Spiritual abuse victims dialogue with religious and mental health professionals
Open discussion

episodes.title: Overcoming Barriers to Healthy Sexuality for S/MGAs
episodes.description:
Overcoming Barriers to Healthy Sexuality for S/MGAs (Doni Whitsett)

Part 1 of this series discussed some general sexual issues of S/MGAs. Part 2 addresses more specific issues with which this populations often struggles. 

The life of a cult child is highly controlled and their personality shaped to conform to the expectations of the leadership. These expectations carry severe consequences when not adhered to. While some groups suppress erotic development, others foster indiscriminate sexual activity creating an atmosphere that is inappropriately sexually charged and overstimulating. Anxiety surrounding sexuality may result in the sexual self becoming alienated. Messages instilled by the cult leader or belief system may continue in a person’s psyche and body after a former member throws off the constricting cult norms and seeks to explore their own sexual potential. Learning to cope with these messages is necessary to be able to engage in healthy relationships. 

Insecure attachments characteristic of families in cults well as messages instilled by the cult often contribute to biological sexual dysfunction.  This talk will address some specific sexual difficulties in the various phases of sexual response (i.e. desire, arousal and orgasmic phases) and offer suggestions for overcoming them.
